												some people might not get the importance of mods in this game,you shouldn't expect to have a lot of fun with this game if you dont play with mods on, because they add so much content and interesting scenarios to the game.in my honest opinion, it's a pretty good game, you'll probably get a few laughs and good times out of it, also seeing as how you can play with buddies split-screen, but you will definately also rage at it once in a while.here's the website of the devs and where you'll find the mods (mods are in the fan forums section); http://datarealms.comi'll list a couple that people should definately check out if they want to play this game here;there are two kinds of mods that you'll find in the fan forums; mods and scenes. scenes are general scenarios, such as a base assault or an entirely redone campaign. mods are, well, mods. factions, weapons, you name it. someone even made a filter to make the game dark and gritty, and someone made tiberium from command and conquer.-Mods-http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=25544Warhammer 40K imperium of man: a massive mod that adds pretty damn overpowered soldiers and weapons into the game, but not so op that it's no fun to play them, you can feel very powerful with the soldiers, but they're not indestructible, and they're fairly expensive. one thing i should note is that with the soldiers with jetpacks you can do a dash in the direction your mouse is pointing by pressing shift+up.there's additional instructions for how to make the individual factions other than the standard blue space marines available on the forum page.http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=11062Unitec: *note: it's very important that you download the 1.05 compatible version that weegee posted on page 136 of the thread. otherwise it wont work, unless you're using an older version of the game.*the unitec mod is really amazing, it adds 3 inredible factions into the game which each have a big variety of weapons to use, it's really incredible how much this mod has to offer. i'd like to note that you can enable hidden weapons in Unitec.rte/Devices/Weapons.ini and change the ones you dont see in the in-game menu to either 1 or 0 (depending on what it's already set to)http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=17247Darkstorm: very cool mod with quite a few interesting devices that will light your enemies ablaze (the fire on them will light other units that walk into them on fire as well) or freeze enemies to death. the warhammer mod uses this fire mechanic as in their mod as well.http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=18120SAW: you should really just take a look at the thread, the artwork that's been done of this is incredible, and it's fairly satisfying to use as well.http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=20028Kettenkrad's wehrmacht: this mod. this. mod. it's nazi and absolutely fabulous. i've seen tanks and artillery as well in this mod, but i think they were in earlier versions of it. it's worth a try to install earlier versions of it and see if they still work. i'd also like to post and additional mod for this one, since it fits very, very well. yes indeed, 'tis undead hitler. (none's post) http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=75&t=24174-Scenes-http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=45538ssl assault: if you're bored of the good ol' bunker breaches, this is a brand new, easy to install scene which introduces 3 new ones (not under bunker breach, but under a new one called ssl assault 1-3) the first two of which being assaults against the coalition with no counterattacks, and the third being an attack against techion with a lot of counterattack once you reach exit the first building you go into.http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=29714Cortex Shock: HOLY COW THIS IS GOOD, i almost forgot this one, it's an adventure scenario that puts you through various fairly hard levels, get your game face on for this one. there is some mod compatibility in this, but it'll be better explained on the mod page.http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=31063SHIELD: Under Siege: this is a scene that requires the Unitec mod i listed, it's a fantastic campaign with 14 levels that each has unique oblectives and hardcore gameplay, very very fun, but be careful not to lose your units, you will instantly lose. the mod is discontinued, but there should be enough content to make anyone happy. i very much recommend getting this mod.http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=12807http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=17619http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=25113Prison Escape 1-3: i really think you should just start playing this without any other words from me. 3 fantastic missions with an incredible feat of scripting at the end.http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=31383Unmapped Lands 2: this scene is very simple to play, but it can also get very long the longer you play, because the AI gets so much gold that he simply never runs out when he's attacking you. there's a manual in the thread for how to play the games.and that's it. i hope you enjoy playing with mods, since i certaintly have done. there's a bunch more mods on the forums that you can find, but i'll leave it there.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												This is the best game with a Metacritic score of 44 I've ever played.Hell, this is one of the most compelling games I've ever played, period. I never got into the metagame, but the individual battles -- where you're digging for loot so you can buy wobbly inverse-kinematics-y troops who arrive in unreliable crashy spaceships and stomp uncertainly across a mushy, shifting battlefield (partially composed of the corpses of previous troops) and then blast off in jetpacks, sometimes splattering against walls, so they can have a chance at maybe putting a bullet in the head of a flamethrower-wielding crash test dummy -- are CRAZY and WONDERFUL.No description can do justice to the joy of crashing a tiny high-speed rocket full of bombs into an enemy stronghold, or sneaking a lone, powerful (but, again, VERY wobbly) robotic commando through a labyrinthine base equipped with nothing but a plasma pistol and a grenade launcher. This is one of those games where failure is every bit as exciting as success. And the mod community is very active, so if you want to play as a wobbly, two-dimensional Gordon Freeman or Emperor Palpatine, those options are available to you. Cortex Command is a game about physics and glorious stupidity. It's a game about ricocheting a sniper rifle shot off a set of doors and accidentally knocking the rifle out of your own hands. It's a game where, when you're sent to retrieve an object, you sweat the ENTIRE TIME because you're afraid you'll drop the object down a hole or accidentally jetpack yourself right out of the level while holding it.This game is bliss.

number of helpful: 73 of 81 people (90%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Don't be fooled by my hours, I played the Non-Steam version quite a while.A lot of people seem to be confused by this game. They probably expected some epic story mode or intense multiplayer battles, and end up disappointed because CC doesn't have these features. But it has something different: An incredible sandbox experience. Do you want to know how I play it? I load up a map of Skirmish Defense, enable unlimited gold and that my brain can be placed anywhere, then build an unbreachable subterranean bunker and start the game. Now the real fun begins. Wave after wave of enemies will try to tunnel a way to my brain, but this task is a bit complicated by the fact that I constantly drop crates filled with pineapple grenades and molotov cocktails on their heads and watch their bodies explode into gore.Soon, the whole battlefield is covered in body parts and debris. The never ending waves of enemies have to crawl trough a horrible mess of blood and flesh from their fallen brethren, only to be ripped apart by the next crate bomb. If this gets boring, I set up a Sniper with a high powered Anti-Vehicle rifle on a hilltop. It is just too damn entertaining to shoot out a drop ship's engines and then finish the remaining crew with a single, multiple-body-penetrating shot. The completely desctructible environment is just so awesome to mess with. When you fire bullets at the ground, you can see them traveling through the dirt and coming to a halt. The game even takes into account what weapon was used - bullets of rifles will bury much deeper than the ones of pistols.This also introduces some interesting mechanics in terms of bunker design. Depending on the angle from where the shot was fired, a bullet will either bounce off a wall or penetrate it.Exploding grenades produce shrapnel that rips apart even the toughest enemy. There is even a Chainsaw Gun. Guess what it does. Yes, it fires Chainsaws.The only problem with Cortex Command are the lazy developers. This game has been in development forever, and nothing significant has changed. The devlog is updated twice a year max, and it's been ages since the last release. This makes the 20$ pricetag feel like a rip-off, since you're buying an unfinished product that probably will never be finished. If you can pick it up at sale, though... go for it!

Posted: November 21, 2015
												Jesus, this game is amazing.It's like that time when you were a kid, and you had your action figures and were all like "OH NO, ROBOT ALIENS!" and you had one in your hand and made it cartwheel in, making swoosh noises as it smashes into the ground and looks up all like "ROAR! Robot Aliens are here to destroy you." And then you grab the Master Chief action figure and he's all like "Not today, Robot Aliens!" and starts laying waste to a horde of aliens with a big laser machine gun, but then a grenade blows up next to him, and you pull off his legs and you're all like "Oh no, Master Chief!" and he's all like "Don't worry, I don't need legs to kick♥♥♥♥♥" and you're all like "You kinda do...", but by that point there's a bunch of space marine drop pods all coming down to back him up so it doesn't even matter, and then a bunch more robot aliens start coming in and the space marines and Master Chief are just pumping lead into the main doorway, but then the bullet casings start piling up in the doorway behind them and Master Chief is like "You guys need to get out of here, or you'll end up trapped by bullet casings!" and the space marines are like "That's a ♥♥♥♥ing stupid♥♥♥♥♥justification for a epic sacrifice scene..." and Master Chief's all like "I've definitely had worse." But by that point there's a bunch of AT-STs lumbering for the doorway, so the space marines are all like "later, brah", and Master Chief starts an epic hold out in the room, and a bunch of laser fire blows his left arm off, but he pulls out his pistol and he's all like "SUCK ON THIS, ROBOT ALIENS!" and starts shooting at the AT-STs, which is super useless but it looks really cool. Then, just when it looks like all hope is lost, an inbound robot alien dropship accidentally bumps into a wall as it tries to drop off more robot aliens and it spirals out of control, smashing into the AT-ST's and sending chunks of them everywhere. One of them hits Master Chief in the face and tears off his helmet, and with 5 HP left, as he quickly bleeds out, Master Chief gets one final moment of peace before ragdolling facefirst into a mine and getting blown to ♥♥♥♥ing pieces.10/10(Check the system requirements because the physics modeling is CPU intensive, $20 purchase might leave you a little salty, keep an eye out for summer and winter sales, as it routinely goes down to $5, anything $10 or below will leave you with no regrets purchasing.)

Posted: September 17, 2014
												Awkward, Clunky, and often doesn't work as expected. Normally this would make it a bad game, but you just haven't lived until you've seen a drop ship veer just a little bit too far to the right and cause a 15 man allied platoon to break out into a Decapitation Conga Line with the power of its white-hot main thruster, then immediately thereafter crash into the pile of corpses it just created, explode like it was full of nitroglycerin, AND THEN launch one of it's blast doors across the map, over the mountains of gibs and fallen friends and foes alike, right into YET ANOTHER allied dropship, which then starts the whole process all over again.Mix in mods and add rains of refrigerators, cluster-nukes and even your very own custom gun that presumably will fire a wall of bullets that creates so much recoil that the guy who fired it instantly sublimates for extra fun. Also it's got some neato mechanics and gameplay, but you likely won't notice past the endless downpour of dropship parts and chunks of clone-torso.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												Down to my last guy, missing half my health and completely unarmed, facing an armored Coalition soldier with a minigun. I rocketed into him with my jetpack, knocked the gun from his hands, and then picked it up. We stared at each other for a moment just before I emptied the whole clip into him. Then I hid on a tower top with a scavenged grenade launcher, and used it to take down a whole platoon and a dropship before I finally bled to death. It was a good day.Most of my hours playing this have been offline or with a standalone copy. As a physics sandbox, CC is unmatched. The campaign is fun, but just starting a skirmish and dropping bombs on things never gets old. Unlike so many titles nowadays, there is nothing to unlock, no experience to gain, no hook to keep you playing, and yet I keep coming back to it because it's just enjoyable. Like playing with toys when you were a kid. Not since the original Unreal Tournament have I spent so much time on a game simply because of the moment to moment fun factor. Also, the workshop is populated with great mods. If you can stomach a certain amount of wonkiness and the occasional crash, the game is absolutely worth it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I feel like this game could've been so much better if there was a "soul" to it. It has other more important flaws, yet still I had fun playing it for the first few hours, but it got old very fast. While playing I thought that some small things could've been added to make the player care more. For a "war" game, there's actually no deaths, no characters. Everyone is a robot, nobody seems to care, so why should the player care for casualties, losses or individual unit? I enjoyed the idea of the gameplay, but I think that story and world immersion matters the most in games. I think a story mode should be added, because no matter how good or bad the gameplay is, as long as there are characters/people for who the player starts to care for, the game will be loved. There are games out there that have basically no gameplay at all, but just a very good story ... and those games are a success!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												First of all, don't let the Metacritic score decieve you, it deserves waaaay better than a 44.This game reminds me of those good, old flashgames where you pick your clunky, pixelated troops and let them roam around the map to invade and destroy the enemy's base, i loved those!Well this game is one of those, but sooo much better in every way!This game focusses on building your own bunker to protect your dissembodied brain from the hostiles invading it.You pick your rooms, walls and barricades from a wide variety of different models and easily place them down.Then you choose your starting units from a large list, ranging from zombies to T-1000-ish killerbots which you can customise freely to wield a huge amount of different weapons.Once you've done that, you can switch to any of those units and controll them untill it gets eliminated or you switch to another unit. You can also put it in patroll mode to guard your base, sentry mode to guard a specific area and brain hunt where it will go towards the enemy's bunker and find its way to the brain. And if needed, call down a V2 rocket piloted by a drunk pilot who will probably crash, but still deliver your fully-outfitted troops roughly where you wanted them (or you just lob them from space in a box and let it crash a few metres deep in the sand, forcing them to crawl out of the gaping hole while hostiles throw molotov cocktail inside, fun times!)I must say, this game is very fun to play, Its simple, creative and action packed!Hell, i had a soldier once who faced off agains three other robots, his legs got shot of and his rifle got destroyed, so he switched to his pistol and killed all three of them before bleeding out.It's these awesome moments that make this game so great! Shooting down a dropship and witnessing the soldiers under it getting flattend by it or a squad heroicly fighting off hordes of crash-test dummies while trying to block their entrypoint with a concrete launcher, and all of this happened in those few hours i've played!Worshop makes it even better, adding in units from other games like Warhammer 40K or Halo makes it much more interessting, even adding in a few new maps is always fun!The only downsides i've encountered is the clunky menu, the poor UI, lacking tutorial and the fact that there is no Free camera mode.There barely is a UI besides the circular hold-the-right-mousebutton one which is a little confusing at first, the tutorial is very minimum, but you learn the basics of the game pretty fast anyways. And the camera, well, thats permanently focussed on the unit you are using, so no looking around the place, which is annoying if you hear a dropship nearby, but you can't see it.But for my final verdict, this game is a must-buy for people who like customising their own troops individualy, who like games that tell stories about how badass the units were in that one battle against those 100 crabs and for those who just like building giant, trap-filled bunkers for the CPU to breach (which it will, he'll just dig into the brain's bunker right away)I give it a score of 8.5/10, take that Metacritic!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												In a world where humans have transferred their brains into robot husks and an interplanetary gold rush begins, players must make the choice of either flying a rocket filled with bombs into the enemy brain or simply rush in with a dude with a very large gun.Cortex Command is one of those oddly unique games that are just meant for modding. 80% of the game's content is stuff you'll find in the workshop and on the data realms forums. As for gameplay, it's interesting to say the least. The game is definitely not a realistic combat simulation, but it definitely uses jetpacks in ways they've never been used before. Keep the throttle on for too long and you'll find yourself zooming across the map at the speed of sound. As for actual combat, it's thought out and entertaining. Things such as bullet weight and velocity play a good part in battle; a pistol's bullets will literally bounce off enemies if they're too far away, while a sniper rifle is heavy to carry but can penetrate armor from a good distance. You'll soon find that when you build your base you'll be putting down heavily armored juggernauts with rocket launchers and LMGs since you don't need them to move much (you'll also find weight is a real hinderance since jetpacks are the only real way to move) while your assault troops will probably just have that one remote-detonation-grenade launcher you think is really cool. While most battles have the simple objective "kill the enemy brain", there are alternative game modes available in the base game, like surviving with one troop for a set amount of time or holding down a base being attacked by dummies.Cortex Command isn't for everyone, but if you don't mind a random decapitation becuase you hit the roof from time to time and you're not super serious about realism then this game will be worth the money.

Posted: June 8, 2016
												I've had a hell of a time with this game. I've sent many troops to their untimely demise, won wars, lost some, found true love (Dummy Expansion mod), and mercilessly and slowly killed an unarmed enemy troop with a weak pistol, just to see him suffer. In all my playtime is probably double what it says it is, due to me playing the **** out of my brother's copy before I got the game myself.The physics are quite pleasing, as is seeing an exploding drop ship door take out one of my men on the other side of the map (Fun fact! The doors are actually programmed to have a small chance to aim for your men... Scary.). The pixel art is superb, not to mention how pleasing it is to kill someone. And the mods will probably entertain you for many more hours. In all- in my opinion anyways, this is a pretty damn good game.Shame that the developers seem to be a bunch of jerks who made a bunch of empty promises and then left this game to slowly die with the only thing it has to look forward to is a couple of 'okay' mods due to the legendary modders leaving with the developers. I still recommend it though, but wait until it goes on sale, it's not worth 20 dollars anymore.

												The AI is clunky and buggy, the faction weapons are unbalanced in terms of price and damage, the maps can get repetitive, and it can be laggy at times.Through all of that, the game is amazing. You can have great fun bombing the enemy with crabs, sending your troops on suicide runs, or surviving against waves and waves of enemies assaulting your base, with your gold supplies dwindling and your troops dying by the second. And don't even get me started on how much mods make this game even better.Once you get the hang of it and get past its many quirks and bugs, it's really enjoyable. The physics are good, you can destroy literally everything in the game and shoot limbs off of enemies. With certain mods the replay value can make you want to play it over and over.Note the game IS buggy and lacks a lot of polish which might err some people.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												There are a lot of 'Boo-hooers' and 'nay-sayers' in the review section because of a number of reasons over the course of this game's development. I won't say they're wrong to hold those opinions but I will say they're wrong for trying to sink this game when it needed their support the most. The game is fun, no one will deny that. I would even say $19.99 fun. I spent a lot of time messing with the engine, the scenarios and conquest modes and that was even before it was on steam. There's plenty to do and you can even do it with couch co-op. That comes standard. Then there's the modding and that takes you to a whole new level with added mechanics, ships, characters, factions. I highly recommend the game despite the rocky development due to a miscommunication between data realms and the consumers.This was one of Steam's first Early Access titles as the video tries to describe. It wasn't a good move and many people starting blasting the game with negative reviews which hindered the game's development. Data Realms is a business and it costs money to run it so when the cash flow slows it becomes a vicious cycle of bad reviews, slow profit and slow development. I've been following the game since way back in early stages of development. I know about all the promises that couldn't be kept and sure it's a bummer, but at it's core it's still a great standalone game. The modding community is solid, the local play is solid. You're going to have fun and, since nothing can be done about the fanbase drama, that's all that matters at this point. Who knows with a resurgence of interest Data Realms could finally give this game the TLC it deserved Don't let the reviews sway you from a unique experience that no other game hits quite like Cortex Command. Enjoy the features it has now, then get pleasantly surprised if new stuff comes down the line.

number of helpful: 26 of 45 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												When I first grabbed the game, I was expecting so much more. I had watched videos and done a little bit of research, and the game simply looked amazing for what it was. A unique side scrolling take on RTS.When I actually got to hop in the game however, things went bad fast.First off, learning the controls, even with the assistance of the tutorial was a pain. They only explain the bare minimum in how you can switch out to other units under your influence, and how to control them on a basic level. They tell you nothing of how you're supposed to actually use the unit, or how to activate its various AI scripts and what they actually do. The UI is bare minimum, you have to dig and test everything out on your own just to figure out things that should be presented directly, or have better in game descriptions.While actually controlling your units, you'll find they are slow and terribly clunky. Even the faster/lighter units feel that way, and there's simply no way around. Heavy units are a literal nightmare to move around the map. With heavier units you'll find it almost impossible to reach certain areas, forcing you to use easily killed light units for everything, and only equipping them with the absolute bare minimum to assault the enemy. Attempting to use the AI scripts usually just forces them to saunter off to their deaths, they end up firing into the air blindly or never returning fire, while the enemy computer controlled units decimate your forces from half a mile away with a pistol.While all the equipment and units you can call down are interesting, you'll find yourself most times just calling down basic units due to the cost to protect yourself, while the opponent seems to have near infinite resources he can call on. Even when you have a ton of money it seems to run out in seconds, where there's seem to have no end, even on the easier settings. That and the fact you'll notice the enemy AI is quite crafty in going after your controller unit/brain. Assassinating him from impossible angles, or simply just scuicide bum rushing you, while your idiot AI forces stand there and watch slack jawed, even is they are on sentry/defense mode.There are a number of mods out there that can expand the gameplay, adding modes, areas, new factions and weapons and other things. Some of them are quite excellent, and it's to bad there was such a great modding community for this game, but the developer half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it for about 10 years. Yep, that's right. This game was 10 years in development before seeing a "full" version launch. Looking at the game now you'd probably be wondering where the full version is. It feels much more like a late alpha build, or very early beta. Like I said, it's such a shame there was such a passionate modding community, their talents and time went to waste on a devolper and his half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥game, when the modders could have put their attentions elsewhere and made something amazing in a game people actually care about.If you can get the game for dirt cheap on sale for like 90% off go for it. Simply to check it out, and see "what could have been". The potential you can see in videos and in the game itself is amazing. But, the deveolper simply never capitilized on it, and now it sits as pretty much abandonware, festering here on Steam, where the deveolper is still asking money for a dead and rotting corpse of a product he will never patch, update, touch, or even look at again.If the source code gets released, and others pick it up and do something with it, the results might just be amazing. So keep your eyes open if or when that happens.Until then, stay away from this festering pile of abandonware garbage.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Cortex Command is a game I really enjoy. It has complex strategy, great game mechanics, and replayability. The biggest draw of CC is it's sandbox like nature, allowing you to play around, or give yourself a challenge. The biggest flaw with CC is that it really doesn't have much to do in it, it's more of a game that you'll pick up and play from time to time than a deep game you'll spend hours with. That said, it never really gets old unless you play really often, it has dedicated mod support to keep things interesting, and a great multiplayer mode. It may not be deep enough to be worth $20, but if you are willing to pay that, you'll find a solid game that will stay fun for a long time, so long as you don't wear it out. Cortex Command gets a 7.5/10

												I couldn't honestly recommend spending money on this game.  I believed the latest vid from the developer, stating that a lot of previous issues have been fixed etc, and so picked it up for $6 in a steam sale, but to be honest it must have been pretty bad before if this is supposed to be significantly improved.  It definitely has potential: the combat could be fun if it wasn't so unbalanced, and the destruction/debris is nice.  The split-screen mode is one of the main reasons I picked it up.  A friend of mine who loves quirky indie games was coming over for the evening and this looked perfect.  We're used to playing a fair share of alpha/beta/unfinished Public Domain games where bugs are often part of the charm, but even this was too much for us and we gave up after about an hour.  I've since played it a little more on my own to see if we missed something, but as hard as I tried I couldn't feel anything but frsutration when playing this.If you can figure out how to work around the weird bugs, the swampy controls, and the terrible GUI, then you might like it.  In the interest of fairness, I should say that I haven't tried any of the mods.  I read the other reviews on here and they all seem to agree that you need to try mods to get the most out of this, but my issues were with core things like controls and the single player campaign, which I doubt any mods would address,

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Simply put: Cortex command is very small. It is not a complete game, and it never will be complete. Although it isn't particularly buggy, its lack of content does not excuse its price. This is really too bad, as it is very fun! The physics may not be realistic, but flying at high speeds across the map whilst blasting everything you see, including your own troops, with the various weapons the game offers is crazy fun. That combined with the satisfying way bodies blow apart and bleed powdery blood all over everything makes for a very promising start. Sadly, it does look like the game is dead.Pros: -Very satisfying: Messing around with the in game modifiers and with weapons can create some interesting results, and the gore is very well done despite its simplicity. The mechanics are Cortex's strong point by far, as they offer very comical over the top explosive action that remains organic.-Surprisingly, crate bombs. Simply learning the best combinations of grenades to fill a crate with before scuttling it and blowing half the map up is very fun. Although its technically not really a feature, it was a happy accident. I wont spoil any of the different crate bomb effects, but try them out. (Just load a crate with a LOT of grenades.)-Campaign. I couldn't decide whether to make this one a pro or a con. The campaign is a fun way to add somestructure to the chaotic gameplay, but dont expect much in the ways of strategy and story. In fact, dont expect any. Take this as you may.-Factions: The factions are quite varied. Even if they do all work off of the same rules, they all do the same thing differently. The Coalition combine well rounded and armoured troops that aren't particularly expensive, with sub-par weapons. Their main advantage is their minigun drones, which, despite being practically immobile, can mow down enemies with incredible effectiveness. When used in a group, you can punch through bunker walls with streams of bullets.Then there are the Dummies, who die in about 1 hit, are super cheap, and have better then average weaponry. Good for swarms, has good guns. Their Dreadnaught is next to useless as anything but a hallway defender.The Ronin have better troops then the Dummies, but they still die fairly quickly. They have a heavy which will actually sustain damage and has a helmet, so I recommend using mostly heavies. Despite this, they have arguably the best guns in the game - their heavy machinegun is fantastic, their m16 packs a punch, and the RPG is basically a giant explosive sniper that one shots most things, and sends everything else flying off into the horizon.The Techion have all the coolest guns and the most advanced stuff. Their heavy troop, instead of being beefy, never bleeds. They are light but expensive 0 very expensive. And their soldiers are overpriced. They do, however, have the most broken gun in the game. The Nucleo Swarm can kill anything from pretty much across the map. The Browncoats are gigantic, pricy, and have okay guns.In fact, they are so heavy they dont really need guns. Just crushing people with your face will win the day. Despite this, arming every single Browncoat you deploy with a flamethrower makes for a lethal force, as that flamethrower is... Scary.The Imperatus are not quite as heavy as the browncoats, but they have the most variety in the game. Their scout bots are like dummies, and ought to be used like them. Good for quick deploy snipers, etc. They have an all rounder, and a heavy. Their guns focus on damage, and are thus usually unreliable but effective. Their running theme seems to be load times and single shot weapons.-Excellent semi-retrosoundtrack: It kind of feels like it should be retro, but it isn't. -Charming: The game has a neat visual style and tang, its more then just yet another lazy pixelated "stylized" game, it uses its pixelated style to achieve more then just a retro look, it has its own very cool sci-fi flavour. The backgrounds are well done, and the spaceships and maps do have style.Cons:-Lack of content to keep you playing: If you want to play Cortex Command for any longer then a week, I hope you like mods. -Crazy pre game load screen: Though its not as bad when you dont download any mods, I strongly recommend you download mods, sooo...It can take up to like 5 minutes just for the game to start up with mods, which is bad.-Unbalanced: Whether or not this game really needs balance is debatable, as its more focused on action then anything. But I mentioned the Nucleo Swarm - there's more. Browncoats pretty much trump everything, and the Dummies are hopelessly underpowered, even with their devastating guns. Plus, I also mentioned crate bombs. You can win the game with them, without even paying much money. Not to mentioned, just stacking 10 soldiers with heavy weapons in one place and forming a squad will allow you to erase the map with bullets. Dropships can fly into things, killing everything, meaning you can win every game in campaign if you just kamikaze the enemy brain with your dropship at the beginning of the game. Luckily, the A.I. does not partake in such horrors, so you can just play honerably and ignore the imbalance.-Lack of strategy and skill involved: this can be forgiven for the games focus on action and stupid situations, but it is true that the game isn't hard to master. The only difficulty you'll have getting in to it is the controls (get to that in a sec), and mastery doesn't go much farther then learning how to control the jetpack and how to melee. (By flying into people at high speeds and using your face to merge them into the ground, gibbing them, spoilers.)-Controls: They are... Incompetant. Though after my time through the game (dont get me wrong, I actually love this game) I have learned them, beginners will have a hard time figuring out the questionable menu wheel. The WASD part is easy enough, though you do have to get used to the physics, (its a bit like playing octodad at first, expect to spend most of your time in the tutorial hurdling out of control) its the command wheel thats the problem. In order to do simple stuff like reload, you have to right click and release on a certain point on a wheel. This can be tedious, especially before you start to learn to do it naturally, and even after.-Terrain issues: Anyone who has played Browncoats ona snow map knows my pain - you will get stuck. A lot. Especially when tunneling, which is a big part of this game, you will spent most of your time hopelessly trying to get you face out of that pile of dirt. Single floating pixels and stop you dead, making you have to squirm to destroy them and move on. Every unit moving like they wet themselves doesn't help, and if you dont have a jetpack, god help you.Overall, I have a hard time recommending it at full price, BUT - do not pass this review as pureply negetive! If the game is on sale or you have extra money kicking around, its worth a weekend of hilarity and fun. Its really too bad, becuase despite its numerous issues, the game is fun to play. So if you want it, get it, but like I said, its not quite worth the money. With mods it can be pretty fun, especially the joke mods that just add stupid stuff. I did recommend simply becuase its got too much good going for it for me to say its bad. Its not "potential," it is a good game as it is, it just lacks content. 6/10, worth a look, but rarely keeps you for long.

content:

												I bought this game off humble bundle back in early alpha.  I loved the promise of wacky robots fighting, blowing up in hilarious ways, procedural destruction, all that jazz.  I've waited a very long time for that promise to become a reality, and I am officially bitter.  Fast forward to today and you have the developer in his snazzy new video making more promises and explaining how he was the inspiration for Minecraft and how the steam launch was a miscommunication and he's getting back on track, all while wearing a tee-shirt marketing his next game to you at twice the price.  Here's a thought:  Demonstrate that you *can* make a game by actually finishing the first project before taking on an even more ambitious project and overselling that.  At least they're telling people on the PP forums not to buy it if they don't like bare bones engines, and I'd tend to agree and recommend the same for anyone looking to buy this.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												This game reminded me of Soldat and a bit of Liero upon first glance which led me to putting it on the wishlist. The concept delivers interestingly enough but some players will feel empty after the game is done. It does have its perks playing with friends as any game does.Cortex command is a two-dimensional strategic and action game that requires the player to make decisive decisions in building a better offense and defense. The goal of the game is to keep your brain alive as this brain is the control center for all the robots and AI that work around it. The brain is either in a mobile suit or is hidden away in a cavern inside a base. There are a few game modes in Cortex Command such as skirmish/mission battles and campaign. Skirmish you can set your own conditions whereas mission battles have objectives (such as retrieve the chip and put it on a rocket then fly it away). The campaign is pretty cool and interesting as it let's you build up a base, conquer and expand your empire. The campaign starts with a few selected places where gold deposits are found. Upon finding these deposits, the player is asked to choose where to go. You may only go at one place at a time but can manage multiple places given you own more.Once the player has chosen a location, the player can blindly jump into the area (which a fog of war will be on) or can actively scan and place their ship as they are scanning to try and get a better location (for defense or for more gold). Players should be wary how much they plan to spend on their expedition though. The one resource that runs this world is gold. Gold is used for everything so your job is to make sure it's distributed evenly. Going on an expedition will cost as well as scanning the surface. If you didn't allow for enough money to start-up, you could be very well losing land quite quickly. Overspend and leave future endeavors and other locations without a defense budget. The computer may attack two locations (as in one may be  your base and another may be a location you're looking to acquire). It is important to leave some money for base development in places you have settled. This lets the AI portion of the game take over and build for you. If you do like building yourself, this is also possible as well as placing objects and especially other units. Having more units will make your location a lot more secure. Just don't forget to arm them! To dig or construct, players need those specific tools to do the job. AI can be assigned to automatically do tasks if you tell them to by holding the right mouse button (which brings up a wheel) and choosing with the left. Players can build in-game and with the designer out of a mission. On the battle-field, the player orders new units or supplies by buying them and shipping them in VIA rocket. These rockets can also be controlled and can be used to blow up other units after dropping yours off.Movement and controls in the game are decent. The movement is a bit weird as the terrain will rip away slowly whether you walk, fly or jump on it which makes moving itself a little weird if you're on the ground. The "loose-body" impact is pretty cool but fly to quick and land with a crash can take some hit points away from a unit (and possibly make him drop his weapon). You can crouch and fly but there are no other action movements or dodges to perform. The point of the game is to make a nice balance between units that mine for gold, that attack and that defend (the brain). You can do this all manually yourself and even form squads or assign certain tasks for individual units. The brain unit (if in a mobile suit) can also perform these tasks. Careful though as I failed some missions due to my brain guy digging outside of the map area and killing himself. This has only happened on scenario maps not campaign maps as they do a full circle (meaning the player can attack from the left or the right).The graphics are decent and are mostly pixelated. This is not too much of an issue if you've played games like Terraria, Nidhogg, Soldat or Liero. I personally like the theme chosen as it suits the environment well. The sounds are varied but can become very familiar after playing a few games.Overall, not a bad game and worthy of a purchase on sale therefore I will recommend it within those conditions. For full price, it's a little steep I'd say unless it really appeals to you. If you have friends, I'm sure you'll find it worth it. Playing solo and finishing the campaign will leave you wanting more. Problem is, you'll have to restart the whole process again. For some players (especially ones that like to build-up like in Terraria), this may turn you off. Good concept, just needs a variable X to make it that much better.RATING : 6.85/10Gameplay C+ Story / Campaign C+ Visuals / User Interface C+ Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability C+ Overall  C+

												I had the early alpha version of this game from humble indie bundle 2 in 2010. I thought it was a great game. It only had two levels, no full screen (or generally 'settings' of any nature), and skeleton gameplay mechanics, but it was very fun and I played it for weeks. It is now five years later, the game is STILL in an early state (even though its official release date was a couple years ago), and aparently all it does now is jump around for a moment, freeze up and crash.I'm not recommending this game because it is clearly an abandoned project. It is a great design, really, but unfortunately also not happening, so you'll just be throwing your money away. I'm lucky I got it in the steam winter sale for only a couple bucks. We'd be luckier still if another company would take over and resume development. Unless that happens, you're betting off skipping this tragedy.

												If you're looking for a single player game, do not buy this. While it can be fun alone, it doesn't offer enough content in the base game to justify a $20 purchase. That being said. Cortex Command is best played with at least 2 people, all with controllers, on a large screen. Featuring somewhat janky but suprisingly tight platforming and even-jankier base-building mechanicsOn top of that there's tons of mods to choose from to make it more challenging, or more funny, more hectic, mostly in the form of faction mods. If you do buy this, do me a favor: buy a few dozen crabs (they're free), throw them into a drop crate, and plop it anywhere.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												This is an extremely amped up 2D game that depends on the modding community. The metacritic score was likely formulated in an early build and without considering the mods. For example Gamespy said, "In a way, Cortex Command seems like it's asking for a lot of concessions because, for the most part, it still feels like an unfinished game." Another example is what IGN said, "Not COD. 5/10." Just kidding. But seriously screw IGN. If you played only what IGN said was worth playing -- could you imagine? To explain how ridiculous it is to review this game without taking the mods into account I will say this. If I recall back when I played on Build 23 the game itself was like 50-60 MB in size and the mods were nearly 3 GB. That's like playing Skyrim with 700 GB worth of mods. This is an Indie game that has it's own standards and priorities that diverge, tremendously, from that of AAA titles. There are so many games that seek to limit the player into a narrow and limited vision that a couple developers had. This game is not like that. I think if all you play is the currently popular games then this game will be an empowering experience for you. This is a game that is wide open for you to change. Play this game. Mod the hell out of it. Learn how to mod the mods. There is so many little things that are just so satisfying about this game, so jump in and find what satisfies you.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This is a good game for maybe 2.50 but the controls are a nightmare. I just came from playing a match where you have to evacuate a brain from a base. This would seem simple enough, exepet for the fact that with the reload action being the same as the pickup action youll be picking up worthless weapons that way you down. This gets extremely annoying because there is always loose guns from dead people everywhere. The ladders mixed with the jetpack are also terrible because the mechanic for the ladders is like glue and the jet pack pushes you forward into it so you always get stuck in a small corridor trying to just fly about a meter up to get to the next section. If you try to use the actual ladder, it seems your guy will just get tired and randomly fall off of it. I didnt know they uped the price to $20 (seeing how I got this in a humble bundle a while ago) but the fact is that this game isnt worth the $20... at all.

number of helpful: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												I love this game! Its like worms with soldiers in real-time plus some strategic elements. However its hold back by the lack of updates and performance issues when there is a lot of action. I heard that this game is awesome when playing with a friend (thus avoiding some AI issues). I haven't yet, so I talk about single-player only here!Sadly campaign mode with AI enemy seems broken. AI is kinda hard in an unpleasent way. You should build a bunker but realy the best bet is to raid the enemy as soon as possible taking lucky shots at his commander. Also the enemy can do multi-tasking (build base and attack you) while the player can only do one thing at a time. Its sad but the campaign mechanics seems broken to me because of this (or better - the campaign mechanics do not play well with the games strengths). It is still fun, especially the missions, but I can't keep looking at the issues and the fact that the game seems abandoned by its developer.Like said, I love this game but unless it is updated to address the issues I can not recommend it for the price of about 19$.If anything, grab it on a sale and try to enjoy the better working missions - you'll either love or hate it.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2012
												Eleven years in the making and the game still isn't finished.Don't get me wrong, it's -playable-. Fun, after a fashion. But it lacks focus. The AI is infinately better than human players in the battlescape screen because it cheats*, and the human controls are badly implemented. It is far better to set the AI on your robots to attack, then step away from the controls, and occasionally buy new ones to throw into the grinder. As a person to person multiplayer, it could be good, but it also loses a lot of the building elements, simply because human players are not going to stick around to micro-manage base building, so again, better to let he AI decide on base structure. Also, there is no online option. It plays only in split screen on controllers. Last but not least, it also does not recognize victory conditions (All except one player eliminated). I bought this in a Humble Bundle while it was still in production. I do not feel ripped off, but would not buy in its current form.*100 percent accuracy, knows where all resources are, is able to control multiple units at once.

												having played 118.1 hours on this game I can safley say that this game is fun and entertaining and a perfect blend of combat, strategy, and constructionsome of the things I like about this game- degradable/destroyable terrain, construction, and rubble- the factions all have unique weapons and units that make each one original and a different playthrough every faction- the multiplayer helps entertain friends/guest, but it isn't the main focus of the game and the ai is compitent which makes playing alone just as fun as with others- I like how if you aren't great at building bunkers, there is an auto build in campaign mode that takes your avalible reasorces an builds a base for you, and in skirmish (quick game) mode building isin't always the main focus-lastly the game is nolonger extremly glitchy, in fact I have never encoutered a glitch in all my time playing-the game is realistic in the sense that if you get shot to many times, without a med bot you will bleed out, instead of running away to a corner and wiping the strawberry jam off your face like in most war gamesand so I would rate this game a solid 12/10

												If you like worms armaggedon than Cortex Command is for you.  If you like RTS's you should consider CC. There is a healthy amount of Mod support from the community and I would love for this game to have a sequel that builds upon and improves the quality of life CC.  I know a lot of people who do not enjoy this game for a variety of reasons but I love it and I know that buried inside of Cortex Command's brain bunker there is a virulently enjoyable game that PERHAPS could use more polish but it certainly DESERVES more love and attention.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												While people complain that it is "missing" core features, I believe not so. The game, itself, is very simple, containing mostly of factions, and modern to futuristic weapons. The downside was that it was not enough to satisfy the audience. When BUILD 30 came out last year, the game basically added the best feature (so far). Steam Workshop, which includes mods so strange and epic, has filled those "missing" gaps. The mods can range to a crab army to a super smart computer that can rupture brains, build structures, and more. Also, the physics are another thing people don't look at. Some moments in the game are like movie moments and that they are NON SCRIPTED. Now that just blew me away when I first played it. Now, if I had to have one downside to this game, it would be that if you install TOO many mods, the game will take forever to load. You should take my word instead of others and get this game, you will not be dissapointed and if you are... Refund it.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												I saw my enemies dropping from a done so I used a grenade launcher to knock out the left engine. It cirlced in the air and flew down into the soldiers, killing them. The parts flew and killed my solder. I came back and that wreck didn't disappear; it was part of the landscape. This game has 100% (100% is not an exaggeration. It is one hundred percent deformable) deformable landscape which means if you're standing above the room where your enemy's main brain is hiding, you can have a squad of your soldiers armed with shotguns shoot a hole through 5 foot thick concrete and wires and rebar where your squad will fall onto the brain-droid and 2 soldiers, killing them all. Your gun can be knocked out of your hand and even broken by gunfire while you're using it. Your legs can be shot off as your arm can be. I spent 30 solid seconds flying around, limbless, with my jetpack when I flew into an enemy and killed him with the impact. Dead bodies also become part of the landscape. I've taken cover behind 3 of my comrades more often than behind actual cover. The command mechanics are *extremely* unique and interesting, and the plethora of mods in 2 days is staggering. I'm sure you've exaggerated the greatness of a game, maybe even said that you couldn't possibly tell someone why the game is so good and they just have to see for themselves but... You really have to see for yourself. I believe it's still 10 bucks but 20 is more than fair. I bought Cortex Command with LEGO The Hobbit, which I'd been looking forward to since March and I've played about 45 minutes of The Hobbit in the past 2 days. Total playtime in those 2 days was 18 hours. Do the math.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Never before have I wanted to give a middle-thumbs for a game as much as I do now. Cortex Command is an incredibly depressing game. It's a beautiful brainchild of a passionate person or people who just did not want to polish their ideas. They game has been in development about eight years now, and it's still in a miserable state. It's horribly bug ridden, there are amazingly careless and obvious mistakes and errors, there's huge balance issues and very little depth, and it's stagnated for a ridiculous amount of time. This game is going nowhere. It's a perpetual prototype, seemingly never to be fixed or improved. A prototype with game-breaking bugs, including the overworld map not fitting on the screen, or fullscreen causing immense lag, or you just getting stuck in a wall all the time. Not to mention the game has prolonged lagging episodes constantly.But what a fun prototype it can be. The game is at times incredibly tense as you try to find an opening to shoot while desperately trying to avoid having any bit of you out in the open, and the game is at times hilarious as drop pods go astray and crash into a squad of troops. It is perfectly viable to win by dropping a crate of crabs on the enemy brain's head. They game is incredibly silly, but also extremely engaging. It takes a lot of effort to take down some of the enemies, and it feels very rewarding when you manage to do so. The base game has incredibly potential.Let's talk about the actual game for a second. It's a 2D shooter with strategy elements. It's very hard to compare, there's really nothing like it. You have your typical base building aspects; you want a unit or two mining for gold, yet you also want a few armed units hanging around defending your brain/HQ. Most of the time you're be controlling a single offensive unit of some sort, kitted out to your liking. You have to make sure your brain lives, and the enemy's brain dies.It's set in multiple scenarios. There are a few separate missions, including a horde/defense mode and a few assualt based modes. There's also a campaign mode, where you will capture points and build bases on them, then try to take over the opponent's bases. Although, that mode suffers from the previously mentioned glitch concerning the overworld map, making it so you cannot see and select some of the base building points, making it impossible to win. And that's it. You got about five missions and a frankly boring and repetitive campaign mode and that's it. There are a few nice mods that add some, but it's just a bit more icing atop an inch-tall cake. You ought experience everything the base game in about four hours, you can add probably add another four to six with mods. It depends how much you can stomach before getting bored.The game has a very robust physics engine which allows you to contort into all sorts of hilarious positions, but it is also incredibly clunky. The menues are a mess, the characters are extremely slow, and you will accidentally kill yourself in hysterical yet infuriating ways. This is a good and bad thing. At first it's novel and interesting, then it's incredibly frustrating. Then it's a bit easier, then it grows fairly boring. There is a huge arsenal of weapons, but a lot of them feel the same, and a lot of them are somewhat disinteresting. Again, the base game is there, and it's great, but there is absolutely no filling, and there is bare minimum content. Your enjoyment of the game will depend entirely on how much you can put up with repitition and how far the bare basics of the gameplay can carry you.In the end, I cannot recommend Cortex Command at the asking price of twenty dollars. That's simply too expensive for so little content and polish. It's also a game that I don't entirely feel comfortable supporting, as it's eight years in development yet still contains crippling bugs. It really feels like the developers just didn't want to bother polishing their initial ideas, they didn't want to do the boring parts. It's like an unedited paper, they just wanted to jolt down all their interesting thoughts and conclusions but they didn't want to spend time making it presentable to an audience. Such a shame.On sale, you might want to consider it. It's got a few laughs and fun moments between the frustration of the brief experience, and it has a lot of toys for the more imaginative players. If you like weird 2D shooters with comically spasmic physics engines with some resource management, wait for a fifty percent sale bringing it down to ten dollars. If you're not interested in that or you can't stand major bugs or you need significant motivation besides gameplay, avoid it like the plague. Also, don't bet on this game ever being finished, or even improving significantly. Eight years of dead air does not bode well.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Lets just say, that this game is a carnage simulator. Those that make you want it? No? Well then.Cortex Command, a pixel art game about doing the campaign or some one time missions, what makes it unique for me? Destruction and the ways you can deal them. The game offers many factions by default, but you can expand with the Steam Workshop. Star Wars? Why not. Some plain weird stuff? You name it. The game uses weight of guns and your soldier to determine "Will you fly or get stuck in the ground?" The combat is quite challenging and fun. The guns can get detroyed, ships get blow by rockets, and soldiers made into blood with A pulse digger. Bullets need time to hit the target, and rockets are slower and able to shoot off the sky. The maps itself aren't that big in wiidth, but is big in height, so much space for some space or mining action. Many modes to play, most likeable is probably Skirmish Defence aka. "Make yourself a base and protect your brain with all you have", just remember to get max money for the destruction :)Well, this review isn't much of an review, but the game is fun as hell. Get it on♥♥♥♥♥or on Steam and blast those maggots out of existence

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I have been following this game for a long time, since before it was on steam.  The modding community is great and it adds so much to this game.  I love the 2d style and destructable enviornments, however I could not honestly reccomend this game. The issue here is performance, on multiple rigs I have had issues with not only crashing to desktop, but crippling lag as soon as a game runs too long or things start to get interesting.   It's almost to a point where it is unplayble.  Unfortunately, it does not matter what type of rig you have,  because this game only utlizes 1 cpu core and limited GPU as far as i know.  Either way the lag always creeps up and ruins the experience.    I don't know if there is a fix for this because the engine it was built on is old.   I don't see how they can recommend playing this with 4 friends, when the lag crushes the experience with just two people.  There are some tweaks for this online, but nothing solid to get the game running at 60fps consistently even on modern pc's.   All in all it has so much potential but It cant be realized because of the dated engine and lack of optimization.

												I wanted to like this game and booted it up a few times. There's definitely a brilliant game there underneath a clunky moving and confusing UI but I didn't have enough time and energy to get to that point. Cortex Command is basically an sidescrolling RTS with full unit control. You can purchase droids and weapons for them + a lot of other stuff I never saw but only read about - while mining more gold to get more stuff. This is definitely a game that you have to "study" in order to enjoy and is not recommended for those that can't invest the time to learn all the tricks and tactics after figuring out what you can do with all the options.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												It's one of the most overlooked games on steam, delivers amazing 2D warfare set in the future, the goal is simple, kill all brains of your enemy, with your units controlled by said brain, by any means available.. Let me just tell you, the amount of ways in which you can kill your enemies? PLENTY, drop a soldier in a crate right on your enemies units, or rockets as they fly in, bombard your enemies with napalm, or other rockets dropped from the sky. Alternatively, just send your units in, and kill your enemies with brutal force. After you kill a brain in one of the areas, you take it over, and build a base, in which your brain will be stored, enemies will try to take over, and will use any means necessary to achieve victory. And that's just the tip, there is a lot more to it, and is best played with friends on a couch. THE BIGGEST FLAW is lack of online multiplayer, which is really sad, and I really see no reason to why that is.. :(All in all I strongly recommend that you play it, and here is a video of couch play I did with my friends, a videos against AI are also available so check them out, they are real fun as well :)

												Some nice ideas on display,and I particularly like the digging for funds and tactical advantage aspect.  But there are so many little things that summed together make a deeply unsatifying play experience.  The movement is clunky at best, the AI for your units is like herding cats through interprative dance, the UI is poorly executed & even the digging I praised before becomes frustratingly slow and tedious.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Cortex Command (as far as I know) is still in development and it does show. The game works but movement can be very wonky. Movement is also very slow which I feel should be updated in the future. With that being said, this game holds soooo much potential and it's worth keeping an eye on. It has one of the best intros I've seen in gaming. It's a sandbox/strategy/combat game. It's very unique in its appearance and gameplay. You basically have a disembodied brain and with that single brain you can jump between and control different mechanical bodies. You then use these bodies to protect your brain and mount an attack on the enemy. The game lacks refinement but it will be interesting to see where it goes from here.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Started a scenario battle. Faction VS Faction.Battle starts and most of my troops are getting slaughtered like pigs.I then take control of one soldier, as i fly down the stairs with my jetpack my leg and arm get blown off by a laser beam.I duck behind cover as an AI soldier shoots the guy next to me. His guts splash on my face.I move in for the kill with my heavy digger. The digger runs out of ammo just as i touched his face.3 shots. *BANG* *BANG* *BANG* My head explodes.I take control of my last guy, a guy with a grenade launcher. I fire my weapon and it is a direct hit.I say ''HOLY SH!T'' as my brain and my whole base is vaporized by a vanilla troop with an op as f*ck gun.

												This game is cute, but it is incomplete and only worth 4.99$.Do not buy this game at its full price like I did. The content is so small and it's basically just one battlefield.If this game were to get more work done on it, it might be worth more money, but considering they advertise as 11 years in the making, it seems like this is a same game that was made in 2001 and was ported to Steam in its incomplete state.A few menus also give you placeholder text for certain menus that says "the developer was too lazy to write a description here" for a few windows. A warning in the campaign menu says the campaign mode is not yet complete (this is after 11 years).So yeah, 4.99$ game. That is all it's worth.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Gigantic quirky sandbox. Has its pros and cons. Movement and derpy AI are the main problems at first. Easily moddable, and even a completely new person can learn to change some arguments on current items to their liking or just to see an explosion with 500 grenade fragments. The mods make this game, so be sure to browse the workshop. Overall enjoyable and interesting, solid 7/10 for me.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2012
												REALLY REALLY awesome indie game! Imagine a sandbox strategy game with realtime Worms gameplay and base building: create a base & the layout ( rooms, corridors, doors, defenses), add soldiers (which also can be finely tuned with different armour, weapons, tools) & try to destroy the opponents brain whilst protecting yours, plus mining gold to supply more reinforcements with better weapons.The terrain plays a very important role. It's fully destructable, being able to shoot through scenery & dig/explode a new path, or it can hinder you as when the bodies & debris pile up, they become part of the scenery & will hinder movement & bullets.There's alot of physics involved in the game, so movement takes ALOT of getting used to, & the game is still buggy, but so far it's been extremely fun to play, hope the developers keep supporting it!Overall, if you're looking for a game that lets you fully customise your base, soldiers & gameplay, THIS is the game you are looking for!

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												A lot of people these days like to play those games with stellar next generation graphics, and that is completely fine, but games like Cortex Command, styled sort of like Terraria, is in my opinion much better than a lot of games. Although I can barely survive a few waves with my meager heavy marine and his compact assault rifle, I love to see the little soldiers fight and ragdoll all around when they get hit, or crush each other trying to get out of a pit. On top of that its actually in my opinion fun to lose here, so I'd buy this if I were you.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Imagine Soldat, but with fully destructible environments, realistic physics, and the ability to build and man your own bases and command dozens of troops. Excellent mod support for adding new guns, soldiers, vehicles, levels, base components, and even entirely new game modes.Also, there's a rocket propelled chainsaw. :DIt's not for everyone, but I love this game, and you should absolutely try it. If nothing else, get a "trial" from pirate-bay, and after 3 days, buiy it if you like it, and uninstall if you don't.It's an absolute blast for local multiplayer, by the way.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Do u like 3D warfare?...well then this game is not for you, this game is a 2D sandbox warfare game in which u defend/attack a brain which controls troops. The whole game is based on gathering resources (gold) to buy your troops to try and defeat the enemy brain. Theres co-op which lets up to 4 players play in one computer. You can also, if you want you can get a Starwars mod for this game where the lighsabers actually work or many other mods which add tons of content to the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												tl;dr Fantastic game, buy it now.I bought this game back in '09 after I played it for six hours straight on a public computer in Kyrgyzstan. I've kept up with the development over the years in short bursts, and I'm glad to see it where it's at today. I've watched so many other games take direct inspiration from it's concept in the mean time, Like Mincraft, Terraria, and games from the X-COM series. It reminds me of playing old-school favorites like Soldat and Liero. If you like fast-paced 2D shooters, building bases, strategy, or digging for resources, I highly recomend CC as it's all of these rolled into one.

												I wanted to love this game. But I can't.Broken controls, it's impossible to capture any bases in the Campaign because the AI is too good even on the easiest difficulty. They never miss but you on the other hand will always miss because the aiming is sticky and flows like a river of bricks. In the campaign my opponent had gotten every base no matter how much I threw myself at them.But the straw that broke the camel's back was when my enemy hd set up a base on a hollowed-out mountain. I couldn't jetpack up enough and I couldn't dig through because it was hollow. I literally couldn't get to themBroken, and for being on steam this long that is unacceptable. Stay away from this.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2012
												I played a lot of Cortex Command back in the day, but I always assumed it would eventually become more of a game. The 'metagame' is pretty strange and unpolished and I can't help but feel the developer just wanted to get it done so he can move on to something else.Still, the game has some pretty amazing physics, where every pixel on the screen feels physically reactive. Filling a spaceship with crabs and crashing it into the enemy base is crazy and fun. The art is very well done and looks great on high resolution displays.Would recommend for people who want a fun split-screen game, but not for the average person looking for a singleplayer campaign.

												This game feels like a game you get for free with something else...and it indeed was in my case as it came in a bundle. I know my hour counter says i sometimes play it, but that is irrelevant as this review is to convince one not to buy it. You can play something you got for nearly free and still advise people to not buy it.Where do i start? Well for starters "DONT BELIEVE THE BUILD 30 TRAILER". back when the game did reach steam it was in fact advertised to its community as DONE and ever since little to no news about it was ever shared and now after a very long time. NOW they show some returned interest in a game and defend it by saying "We should have communicated properly". they had a long time to explain that point and just now they do it. Thats just unexcusible.Onto the game itself...its a tech demo. nothing more, nothing less and it will NEVER be anything but that.The tech is nice and everything, but there just isn't any depth. At most you may mess around in one of very few levels or the kinda chaotic "campaign" now and then with a few modpacks just for the sake of it. but it gets horribly repetetive nearly instantly... There just isn't anything of substance. there was the promise of a campaign with the game's setup (you are a brain on a quest to create a empire on a Free for all planet, neato). but that got shoved aside for the so called campaign currently and only a few scenarios hinting at the original plans remain.Multiplayer is a joke. there is in no way any networking capability and only if you have multiple controllers of any use...only then may you find some enjoyment IF you have the controllers and friends wanting to play...which is more often a big NO.Also the dev shrugged off bugs and "unpolished" features on the pretense of early-access. Thing is that most of these bugs have been there for YEARS.In overall this game is something that began with potential and ambition, but now is horribly dated and the dev doesn't seem to put in any effort anymore. I say that unless the game costs a few dollar and you are willing, to just let it pass into history and to let the dev know that he should probably just move on to something else, cause this is a lost cause.PS: Expect to crash to desktop a LOT when using modpacks. Certain collissions can cause crashes apparantly a bit too often

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												I waited for that game so long, was eager to play with all theses robots in this beautiful environement. I even bought it before it's official release. But once it finally came out...omg, what a disaster.The controls are extremely clunky, i lose robots everytime due to bad robot handlingThe UI is infuriatingly bad. No map or notifications to tell you something is happening back in the base (at least, until it's too late...when you see the red screen indicating your main brain is taking damage, it's too late to do anything about it). So either you constantly jump from your base to your attack force (and pray your attack force isn't doing something stupid while you're not watching it), or you just rush ahead and pray no surprise happens back at the base.The buy menu is full of problems. It takes half your screen, yet is almost unusable. So you will create presets builds to avoid using the menu itself. And then you will find out the presets are also full of problems (can't combine them together, order of items matter, etc...) So the minute to minute gameplay is full of problems, but the overall strategic gameplay is even more broken. It's always very unclear what you're supposed to do. In scenarios, the game may tell you thing like "load onto a ship to escape"..."how am I supposed to do that game ?" "no telling you, figure it out !". And the campaign is in an even worse, you can't figure out what you're supposed to do, and whether you're winning or losing.On the whole, this game feels completely unfinished and/or broken. I'm guessing the designer just said "well we've been at it for years, it still doesn't work, let's push it to the store and forget about it". I'm sadly writting that game off. :(

												This sucker is more recommended than an assault weapon for crowd control. I've waited so  long for this game, toyed with many mods, broke my computer fps many times over with crab bombs and gib overflows, and spent more ounces of gold on the most worthless weapons than you can shake a stick at. Base building? Its like the Minecraft of Military installments (Terraria?). Shooting action? There are so many different guns. Main game too boring? More community mods than you have children to play with. The eleven years its been in development have been great, if boring.While the twenty dollars is pretty steep, I would recommend getting it if you can pony up the money or snag it somewhere. If you can't buy it, or want to know how she plays, I recommend Soldat as a similar horizontal shooter to understand how the genre feels and looks. Plus, Soldat's free.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2012
												I played a lot of Cortex Command back in the day, but I always assumed it would eventually become more of a game. The 'metagame' is pretty strange and unpolished and I can't help but feel the developer just wanted to get it done so he can move on to something else.Still, the game has some pretty amazing physics, where every pixel on the screen feels physically reactive. Filling a spaceship with crabs and crashing it into the enemy base is crazy and fun. The art is very well done and looks great on high resolution displays.Would recommend for people who want a fun split-screen game, but not for the average person looking for a singleplayer campaign.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												If you want a taste of something new, this is for you. This game offers a very unique perspective on strategy, combining the aspects of unit management (I.e. purchasing leading) with compat prowess. The Bunker building system is just great. The game offers a moderatley high learning curve, and features a decent variety of unit, and good variety of weapons.However with no online coop/versus I can see myself getting burnt out afer a few days.And there are a things that irk me at times, such as why can't I clear out deris from my bunkers?Is it woth 10 bucks? Sure, why not?20? No deal.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												This game is a VERY FUN game that is NEVER the same! Fun  wonky destructible terrrain and troops! I love the modding community for this game and hopes it updates more often! ALSO PLEASE add in a way to delete all your mods so the game can load in quickly and a way to put all the mods back in. thanks!The updates are either months or maybe a year apart, none to fear as for the Fresh mods keep it alive... Sorta!  Check out DataRealms' other game coming out April 15 2016 Planetoid Pioneers, the prequel to Cortex Command. Controls are wonky but hey, it adds to the fun and randomness. Also you're are a BRAIN, IN A JAR/ROBOT, controling bodies via microchip signal. Don't blame it for not knowing how to walk but know how to break dance.Matches are very different and chaotic. Needs above decent computer to run it great all the time. Mine gets about 5-20 FPS. 20 FPS when nothing is on the map. 5-10 when killing things on said map. Otherwise Great game if it had updated more often. Mods keep it alive and Replayability is great.
