												While this game has a really cool concept, it's buggy and poorly executed. Basically the idea is that you conrol multiple units in real time to protect your base and destroy your enemy. There is a good variety of units and the terrain is fully destructible but many of the basic mechanics like movement can be buggy and frustrating. Though I'll admit the music is quite good.If I had any confidence that this game would be updated in the future to fix some of these problems I might change my rating, but as it is the updates are few and far between. If this games sounds like something you might like, pick it up on sale, it's certainly not worth $20.

												I really, really, REALLY wanted to like this game but GOD DAMN do the controls suck! Holy crap it's completely unplayable! Is it just me? I can't imagine that there are a whole lot of people out there who are able to actually *play* this game. Aside from the awful control scheme, the mouse cursor/arrow does this weird hurky-jerky thing where it doesn't respond half of the time and the other half of the time it moves contrary to where I direct the mouse. I count this game as fifteen dollars straight down the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The worst part is, I can't even swallow my pride, roll up my sleeves and reach into the (figurative) muck-filled basin, and minimize the damage by retrieving even some of my money. I'd gladly tolerate getting more (also figurative)♥♥♥♥♥♥on my hands if it meant that I could. Unfortunately, Steam is a toilet of the one-way variety. Once the bowels have been moved, there's nothing one can do to change the situation. All dumps are loose, acidic, and FINAL.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Anyone who has ever, truly cared about the RTS genre should want to play this game because it has every thing going for it. If you loved Steel Soldiers, you'll adore this.The original story line and concepts are amazing, the units varied and creative, the guns are very unique and every unit has a jetpack.The units in particular have sometimes amazing AI (units in squad will go prone if they are in contact and the unit behind them is shooting, stop friendly fire with HE) to not so good (jumping in to a cavern with a squad sometimes ends with an AI unit jetpacking in to a wall and staying there). want to position a sniper or rocketeer on a nice big spot height? Jet pack! In trouble and need CAS? Dropship loaded with bombs or rocket full of bombs as a huge missile!Every time you play, you find yourself wondering where the hell this game has been hiding and why no one came up with it earlier and where there are other devs with ideas this original and colourful.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												Cortex Command reminds me very much of a free-to-play browser based game you might find on Kongregate or Newgrounds, except that the games on Kongregate and Newgrounds are actually worth my time and tend to function correctly. I was drawn into the game by it's promise of destroyable maps and epic robot battles, but what I found instead was a buggy pile of jumbled pixels that seemed to have great potential but fell short of it's goal. I owned the game no longer than three hours and for those three hours I regreted every second I decided to add this "game" to my library. I was met with severe graphical issues, I was met with poorly made, buggy gameplay that would make E.T. look advanced, and I was ultimately met with the Steam support window as I asked to have my money refunded.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This game is both good and bad. It's great because it has a unique gameplay system, random terrain generation, and a decently fun campaign mode. The bad side is actually playing the game can be difficult and it's tricky to make wise decisions to stay ahead of the AI and be successful. I mostly view this as an extra challenge, but the heavy difficulty has lead to me not playing this game too much. Overall it's a good game and it's a fun to play. I do enjoy how open-ended it is and how you can be creative with equipment and various purchases you made.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Terrible, just terrible. At first glance this game seems to have a ton of potential. You have a lot of weapons to choose from, alot of equipment and a lot of gear to arm your robot avatars with, and the particle and physics effects are very neat to see. Unfortunately it only takes about an hour of play to exhaust all the fun you could have with this game. Every thing becomes to repetative. Small skirmeshes that range from to easy to almost impossible if you miss manage what little resources you have, and an overall unfocused set of game types thrown in almost as an afterthought. The multiple weapon types offer a bit of strategy to an otherwise mindless game, but once you become adept with some of the more exotic guns the game has to offer, you can abandon any strategy the game has in favor of brute strength.Playing against a human oppenent makes things far more interesting, but having only local multiplayer in this type of game seems like a rather silly design choice by the developer. If this game really took a decade to make, perhaps another year on the design table would have done this game wonders.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												This is an incredible game, i may not have many hours online but when offline, i played this a ton. Cortex command's physics based movement may be annoying and fiddly at first, but when you get the hang of it you will be laughing your head off as you dive at some one and activate your jet pack, sending the flying and smashing to little peices. I highly reccomend this game. The    ability to make mods is incredibly easy and reccomended for begginers, you can simply copy over an existing weapon, change the sprite and alter its values to make a completely different gun :D Hours of fun are certain if you buy this!

Posted: January 21, 2014
												This is a game that some will love and some will hate. With dodgy controls and AI, it can be irritating. But if you tolerate those, then you find a gem. A blood soaked, buried in ship wreckage, gem. And it has a modding community, sort of, and some of them are pretty fun. The Imperium of Man mod is fun. Who needs tactical digging? Who needs "Sending in troops until it works"? Blow a god damn whole in the enemy bunker, then drop in one space marine with a shield and sword. Works every time.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												This game is really hard to explain. It's a 2d side scrolling game where you build a bunker, put your brain as your head honcho inside, and call down a truckload of soldiers to protect it. Or you can try some of the other gamemode's, like the one where you call down soldiers to attack an already existing bunker and win by war of attrition.The physics and way people practically shatter after they die makes for some funny scenarios. Like the time when i killed a bunch of people just standing around, and put my guy atop the mountain of dead bodies as he ripped through reinforcements.The controls are awful (so is this review), but you get used to it after 3 hours really.also crabs skeletons and chainsaw rocket launchers ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												This game is a unpolished, buggy masterpeice.  This game is amazing but it doesn't feel like a real game that has been released.  Even with that though, it is so much fun it is ridiculous.  It's physics based, a jetpack is physically on you and directs you from it's point, if you tilt your torso you fly sideways, not up. If your guy's leg gets blown off you hop, both legs you crawl. Arms and legs you sit there doing nothing. You drop a crate full of 2000 crabs(crabs are free to deploy but crates are not) from orbit onto a spaceship and it explodes like a shrapnel grenade and destroys half of the map and leaves crab limbs everywhere. You fill a rocket with napalm and fly it into a cave with zombies incinerating everything. Try it with friends and it's even better. It doesn't feel like a real game but it really is so much fun I have to recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Interesting ideas, interesting gameplay, nice pixel art, it would have it all...IF it were actually a game.  Alas it is not.Development crawls (to put it mildly) but does actually seem to continue.  But last I tried, it has a main menu, a couple pre-defined missions (which mostly don't work), and a multiplayer that consists of entirely uncontrolled "buying" and home-base creation.Unless self-imposed-rules on top of base building and bot-fighting with bad AI and clunky controls is your thing, skip it.  I really want to say something else because they have a good base, but I can't.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												This is what I would qualify as a mixed review. First of all, I understand fully that the game is being developed. That, and the very fun elements of the game that I have enjoyed have permitted me to enjoy what I got so far, and hope for more. The game is inventive and seems to be a great piece of work. The problems it has fall into three major categories.1) Streamlining.Its pretty self explanatory here, but when I'm trying to build bases or order soldiers / guns, it takes forever to navigate back and forth between the menus. You'll know how to get from place to place after one good attempt, but the actual act of manuevering is never easy.2) Polish.AI needs some work. The bots are at the same time both lethal to enemies and themselves. They're bad at following you,  but sometimes highly skilled at it. They can't hit anything for♥♥♥♥♥♥ one half of the time, and they're Rambo the other half. Some refinement would be much appreciated.3) Glitches and Freezing.I played this game happily with both previous problems until I was no longer able to enjoy it because the game stopped working. It would freeze during loading for around 5 minutes, then load the menu, freeze for a few minutes loading a game, and then again during play. This is a problem for any game, especially ones that aren't finished, but it needs work.Still, after all of this, you should buy this game. Its hilarious and wonky, and sometimes a little unweildy, but its a great game and its worth your time and hard earned cash.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												TL;DR: Great game with a few glaring problems.This game takes the best parts of worms armageddon and Soldat, and then mashes them together in a genuinely enjoyable, frantic RTS.It's not really (at all) balanced, but to me personally that's alright because you'll be playing everything offline anyways.The local multiplayer is CRAZY fun, and there's hardly another game with couch co-op this good.BIG ASTERISK:Programming wise, this game has LOTS of problems. Frame rate drops, crashes, glitches, and more! This can be incredibly frustrating when you've been playing a game a few hours and lose all your progress.Definitely worth picking up, despite its numerous flaws.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Where to start with this game.  I started playing this game long before it got to steam.  It was a far more simple game with just a skirmish sandbox.  The community rapidly grew and the game it self steadily grew.  I wasted so many hours with this game and the many fun mods that have been made for it.  It is really easy to get distracted fighting off a wave of enemies assaulting your brain bunker in wave defense and have a total blast doing it.  It is also very easy to tailor the games challenge level either through built in settings or choosing to challenge yourself with creative set ups.Downsides.  The game can be a bit hard on older computers as the way the engine works requires some decent power to make the game run reasonably well.  Some of the cooler mods have effects and particles flying about in such quantity the game can slow to a crawl.The mod community is normally great.  The steam workshop though seems abit under populated given the overall size of the old community.  Getting updated mods that work can be a bit of problem sometimes.  I haven't played the game as much since it made it to steam but from what I have seen so far it is still the same great game it was when I first picked up years ago.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												One of the best strategy games I have ever played, if you would call this a strategy game. The unique idea and original story make this game interesting, but it isn't polished enough to be called a finished product.Start with a moderate amount of funds and take over a mining site on the planet. The amount you invest in an expidition is the amount you will have to purchase troops, upgrades, weapons. A small amount is taken right at the start of the battle in order to cover the cost of the brain and remote body. If you play smart and use the terrain and your troops effectively you will win without spending much. Simply pouring funds and troops into a battle is sure to make you lose in the long run.Overall the game runs fine. The graphics are almost dated, but they don't look bad. It almost seems like something from the late nineties. Most players will be challenged, but those who enjoy a unique kind of strategy will love it. Try to start a new campaign and learn some of the basics before you form an opinion. There are some bugs, but nothing game breaking. The devs are still working on this game and there's some great add-on content.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Cortex Command is a game I've been following for a few years now, even before it came to Steam. It's a gem, and I'll tell you why.OVERVIEW: Cortex command is a sidescrolling shooting/sandbox game about building bases and defeating your enemies with superior tactics, skill, and numbers. If you were to take Terraria and Team Fortress, mix in some Real-Time-Strategy and add heavy helping of Sci-Fi, you'd get this game.You control units, (via telepathy from your leader Cortex,) from any faction you'd like, and outfit them with the best weapons and tools you can buy, all in an effort to either protect your leader brain, or destroy your enemies'. You can pilot air vehichles, build bases, give your units orders, or command them yourself. There are many different game modes, each of which are fun in their own right. The combat lets you express your tactical skill in any way you can imagine. Drop a crate full of bombs in an enemy's base, crash a rocket through the front door and lead your troops in for a charge, dig underneath their fortifications and attack from below, scale a gaurd tower with a grappling hook, the list goes on. But don't take my word for it, feel free to watch the gameplay videos.PROS: The pixel art is lovely, the controls are smooth, if a bit wonky at times, (though it is a physics-based game, what do you expect?) The combat is all about your skill and how many bodies you're willing to throw at your enemy, and how creative you're willing to get to slaughter your enemies. Base-building has you express your creative side, and, while it can be tedious at times, the possibilities are endless and rewarding.  The workshop mods come in at a steady pace, so you'll never be bereft of new content. Also, if you've got some artistic skill and a little programming knowlege, it's not hard to make your own. CONS:The controls, while smooth, aren't easy to get used to. It's a physics-based game, so your movements are sometimes a bit clunky and odd. The base building also takes a while, so if you're playing with a friend, be prepared to either let the base be built automatically, or be sure your friend gets a turn designing. The biggest problem I have with the game, however, is that it's LOCAL MULTIPLAYER ONLY. That means you have to have your friends at your house, otherwise you're pretty screwed. But this could change in the future, but that's up to the deveolopers.CONCLUSION:All in all, I love this game, it's right up my alley. If you like sidescrolling shooters or if you like building games like Terraria, this game is right for you.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Genuinely, this game is fantastic. the physics engine is weird enough that you can still be surprised sometimes but no longer buggy enough that its frustrating. with the improvement of the object limit, we're now able to have massive battles that can be genuinely harrowing at times. I have had moments where I've been winning a battle by a landslide and they send in troops that absolutely wreck me. I'd then push foreword and get pushed back again and again. the difficulty slider being seperate from the A.I. intelligence slider is also incredibly fun. You can set the enemies to be bullet sponges, sure, but you can also get them to be intelligent and capable of taking you down. the campaign mode is fun at the higher difficulties, but I do feel that some more content and game modes would be fun. All in all, the game is fantastic and I highly recommend it. 11/10 it has eaten my life.Also, I recommend modding this game. Although do be sure to uninstall the mods you don't want and then check to make sure they're gone in the games files, as sometimes steam won't remove them properly and the game gets clogged at start up from tons of files you're not using.

												Cortex Command-A game where you can stuff 50 crabs into a small crate drop it in from orbit onto an enemy base and watch it slowly sink down into the ground and then explode sending crab insides crashing through the enemy base killing all within its reach.I play this on a pretty crap laptop and yes it does lag pretty badly at times. Ramp the diffiulty up to nuts the enemy A.I. up to unfair and give about 10,000 funds and now you're gonna need some strategy. If it was implemented my hours in this game would probably be much much higher. But unfortunately as far as I can gather due to the way the engine is multiplayer seems impossible. But if it is the last thing that the devs ever did for this game I would be so happy.So, Cortex Command. If you want to give your enemy a box filled with crabs as a gift well this is your game.Also- The mods are amazing for this game. 90% of them are to be found on the forums not on the workshop so make sure you go there too if you're looking for some.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Personally I can't understand the negative critics. Yeah, it is wonky at times but that's what makes this game so great. There's just so much stuff that can happen out of nowhere. For example when you order new equipment but all of a sudden an engine from the spaceship that's supposed to deliver your goods blows up, the whole thing starts spinning out of control and rolls over a bunch of attacking enemies. Love it. Also there are dozens of game modes and also almost infinite playing styles. No matter how you want to reach your goal, you can do it, thanks to completely destructible terrain. And this is what makes the game so great, the destruction is just epic. Plus characters and vehicles are also fully destructible, piece by piece. Characters wear protective armor you can shoot off or try and aim for the fleshy head that explodes in a satisfying shower of blood. Vehicles also wear protective armor and if you aim well you can blow engines off of them so they spin out of control. That's the reason why I love this game. There's tons of details built into the satisfying destruction that this game offers.Yeah, the performance is not the best when there's a lot going on on your screen. But even before the Steam version I have been playing Cortex Command for hours upon hours upon hours with friends and we had loads of fun with it. Definitely recommended!

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												Cortex Command is a game where you build a bunker to protect your brain, place your brain inside of said bunker, and then place different types of guards around the bunker so that enemies have a hard time getting in. You then start the game and enemy ships start landing on the planet.Then ♥♥♥♥ gets crazy yo.You are waiting for one of your dropships to bring in more troops since the last lot are currently blocking up the entrance to your base with their dead bodies when suddenly you hear an explosion, so you quickly zoom around the map looking for the source of the sound, and you see that one of your (barely functioning by this point) turrets has destroyed one of the engines of a dropship. You then watch as the dropship spirals out of control, smashes into the ground (and your turret) and explodes. What cargo was that dropship carrying? That's right. Mother♥♥♥♥ing mine bombs. Mines go everywhere. You then realize that your dropship has arrived. but it's too late, and everything explodes in an awesome tornado of dropship bits and body parts.There's also local splitscreen multiplayer. Why haven't you bought this game yet?

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												I really don't understand why this game gets bad rep. Maybe because it doesn't exactly have a fully-fleshed out campaign mode? Maybe because it was in development for a heck of a long time? I don't know. What I do know is it's a ton of fun.It's a physics-heavy 2D shooter where stuff like hit detection is calculated by the PIXEL, and the physics really are the coolest part. You can blast enemies to beautiful bloody giblets with a multitude of weapons, drop bombs to destroy terrain (and soldiers) and when you're done bombing, accelerate your dropship to insane speeds and slam it into anything that's still moving, creating a deadly explosion of fire and shrapnel.If I'm going to be perfectly honest, I have a few gripes with the game myself, but for how incredibly unique it is compared to every other shooter out there, and how fun it manages to be despite being so different, it deserves better than a 44 on metacritic.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												First I would just like to say- Ive boured dozens, if not hundreds, of hours into this, but only just got the steam version. If you like the idea of this game, I would highly advise it, no matter what the other reveiws say, as personally I've found the bugs that do pop up to be forgettable ,and the core gamepaly to be fantastic.PROS-First of my favourite part of this game- local coop- This gmae allows up to four human palyers, with xbox controllers, in nearly ever mission, and can also have a A.I team in there. The primary reason I got this game, and kept it, was for this features flawless implementation.-Huge selection of items- During the game, at any stage you can order a selected type of dropship to deploy units, tools or airstrikes. There are several factions, dozens of varied actors, and probably hundreds of bombs, guns and tools. Also, at the begining of some missions, you have acsess to the entire libary of content to build a customized bunker, that can stretch the entire map. The actors can be customized with every weapon of the game, but overloading them will slow them down, so you have to find the right balance. If the current selection of items is still to small for you, then there is the-Mods- You can fight space nazis with space marines. Enough said.-Gamplay- I'm not denying this game has some issues that need fixed, but this game palys flawlessly in most cases. some movment looks unnatural sure, but at the end of the day, this  gmae is a working mix of world map campaign, squad based , terraria like mining, base building,destuctible enviroment multiplayer shooter. AS much as I love it,, these features also make it a potential CON(S)-Complexity- AS some of my friends who are used to simple shooters like COD said, thsi game is a little complex. Although I think the dozens of diffrent gamepaly elements are as streamlinned as possible, the game still takes a bit of gettign used to. Which brigns me to the second con..-learning curve- Im going to be honest, the tutorial is a bit lacking in its current state, qit hzero info on how to use the campaign menu. However, after lookign up some internet guides, the games secrets reveal themselves quickly.-Clipping issues- As a game with fully destructible enviroments, actors trying to get out of the palyer build catacombs some times get indefinatly stuck on on peices of terrain, but this can be fixed with a quick zap of a digger.Overall, this game is deffeinatly worth getting, esscpecialy since the developer has stated that they have not left this game.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												The controls are a bit clunky, the UI can be annoying at times, and the game isn't very deep. But I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy every minute of this game I've played so far.The game plays as sort of a 2D, side-scrolling RTS. You control individual soldiers one at a time as you move them around the battle field in hopes of protecting your "Brain" and destroying the enemy's. Mine for gold to purchase an air drop of more troops, or hijack the dropship and fly it into your enemies to cause lots of destruction. Not the most polished game, but lots of chaotic fun to be had. Hard to recommend at its current $20 price tag, but definitely worth the buy if you can find it for less during a Steam sale.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Now this is my first review I've written so yeah.This game has taken a crap ton of hours from me, for better or for worse, and what I've noticed from those hours is that patience can be very rewarding, mostly gameplay wise. I've had this game since the latest update 31 came out, and haven't really had any of the problems I've noticed others have had, I'm not gonna name them cuz I am lazy. The gameplay is probably the most open and captivating that I have seen in a game to date, and offers a lot of possibilities and methods of victory. This is aided by the fact that the terrain is destructible, buildings and other fortifications feel "concrete" and wear away over the battle as does the battle field, covered in blood and machine and vehicle parts, and the gameplay mechanic of orbital delivery adds a sense of urgency/excitment to offensive attacks and defensive counter attacks. That said, the gameplay mechanics build up the game, and make it worth playing, now thats not to say that more couldn't hurt, like day and night cycles with the darkness of night adding stealth mechanics and sneak attacks, perhaps a custom weapon maker, firing crabs out of a gun, or maybe water, underwater bases, water traps, water water... these of course aren't necessary but they would add a bunch to the game, and the need for updates is also a concern for me, but hey, if they are on hiatus then so be it. As for its gameplay mechanics such as controlling mass amounts of units and stuff like that it is probably the most innovative I've ever played before, I can be very fun with friends or solo, and once you get used to how the little guys play you'll be setting up sqauds, fortifying your base, hunting for brains, and blowing things up in no time. As for play and replayability, it truly depends on what kind of  system specs you have, if you have a lot of ram opened up, then it should run fairly smoothly, just dont get mods that'll crash the game, and for replayability, if you download some scenarios it can be very worth it, all in all, its a good game with a couple rough edges like not enough maps or slow moving guys but the positives out weigh the negatives from my experiance, so I'd reccomend it.Thanks for reading this far :p

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												This is what I would qualify as a mixed review. First of all, I understand fully that the game is being developed. That, and the very fun elements of the game that I have enjoyed have permitted me to enjoy what I got so far, and hope for more. The game is inventive and seems to be a great piece of work. The problems it has fall into three major categories.1) Streamlining.Its pretty self explanatory here, but when I'm trying to build bases or order soldiers / guns, it takes forever to navigate back and forth between the menus. You'll know how to get from place to place after one good attempt, but the actual act of manuevering is never easy.2) Polish.AI needs some work. The bots are at the same time both lethal to enemies and themselves. They're bad at following you,  but sometimes highly skilled at it. They can't hit anything for♥♥♥♥♥♥ one half of the time, and they're Rambo the other half. Some refinement would be much appreciated.3) Glitches and Freezing.I played this game happily with both previous problems until I was no longer able to enjoy it because the game stopped working. It would freeze during loading for around 5 minutes, then load the menu, freeze for a few minutes loading a game, and then again during play. This is a problem for any game, especially ones that aren't finished, but it needs work.Still, after all of this, you should buy this game. Its hilarious and wonky, and sometimes a little unweildy, but its a great game and its worth your time and hard earned cash.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Where to start with this game.  I started playing this game long before it got to steam.  It was a far more simple game with just a skirmish sandbox.  The community rapidly grew and the game it self steadily grew.  I wasted so many hours with this game and the many fun mods that have been made for it.  It is really easy to get distracted fighting off a wave of enemies assaulting your brain bunker in wave defense and have a total blast doing it.  It is also very easy to tailor the games challenge level either through built in settings or choosing to challenge yourself with creative set ups.Downsides.  The game can be a bit hard on older computers as the way the engine works requires some decent power to make the game run reasonably well.  Some of the cooler mods have effects and particles flying about in such quantity the game can slow to a crawl.The mod community is normally great.  The steam workshop though seems abit under populated given the overall size of the old community.  Getting updated mods that work can be a bit of problem sometimes.  I haven't played the game as much since it made it to steam but from what I have seen so far it is still the same great game it was when I first picked up years ago.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Genuinely, this game is fantastic. the physics engine is weird enough that you can still be surprised sometimes but no longer buggy enough that its frustrating. with the improvement of the object limit, we're now able to have massive battles that can be genuinely harrowing at times. I have had moments where I've been winning a battle by a landslide and they send in troops that absolutely wreck me. I'd then push foreword and get pushed back again and again. the difficulty slider being seperate from the A.I. intelligence slider is also incredibly fun. You can set the enemies to be bullet sponges, sure, but you can also get them to be intelligent and capable of taking you down. the campaign mode is fun at the higher difficulties, but I do feel that some more content and game modes would be fun. All in all, the game is fantastic and I highly recommend it. 11/10 it has eaten my life.Also, I recommend modding this game. Although do be sure to uninstall the mods you don't want and then check to make sure they're gone in the games files, as sometimes steam won't remove them properly and the game gets clogged at start up from tons of files you're not using.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Would I recommend this game? /♥♥♥♥. Yes./ That's all that needs to be said. Don't be fooled with the little time I have on this as of right now, 2.7 hours. I've been playing this for years. Since Build 24. YEARS of being part of this game. Hard at first. Once you spend some time with it though, I'd say a good solid 4 hours, you gain an understanding of controls. For soldiers. It may come faster to you, but the piloting of ships took me a long time. It's gentle but heavy. The AI makes it seem like they stop instantly, but they don't. Enough about that. Review stuff, that's why you're still reading this wall of text.Positives!- Sandbox. So many ways to play this, I can't say I've had a game go the same way. Ever.- Hardcore gameplay. It's not for the average person looking to waste some time, unless of course you want to watch your own units die to the random ship failures.- CRABS! Have you ever dropped a green box crammed full of alien crabs? Doubt it! But you want to now, don't you? DO IT. Never before have you seen the world shift into a lagtastic slow-mo while everyone around the impact site turns into a puddle of red goo as crab shells rain down over the battlefield!- It's still in development!  You'll be seeing builds faster than I did, and that's exciting, because this game needs more love! Keep it up Data!- Mods, Mods, Mods! Hit up the workshop and add some things! And if you go to the DataRealms forums, you can hit up the modding community where it started. The latter is a manual installation, but it's a simple folder into another one.Negatives. (Are there any? Maybe.)- Fullscreen is a total pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get to work, and the normal size for the screen is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to look at.- Learning curve. A lot of games have them, but the controls are a little weird with this. The Pie menu isn't as sensitive as I'd want it, but it does what it needs to once you remember where things are located on it.I wanted to think of more negatives, but I just can't. TL;DR: BUY THE GAME. CRAB BOMBS. SHIP DEBRIS FRIENDLY FIRE. BLOOD SHOWERS. BULLET CASING PILES.10/10 would spend 20oz of gold to cram 500 crabs into a green box and drop it from orbit, killing all life in a 500 miles radius.

												First of all, the positive review is based on more the idea of the game and the potential. This is because the developer has a great game on his hands here but he does not update frequently (its been in development for 11 years) and bugs and crashes run rampant.It is unpolished and by far perfect but you will get some good laughs and carnage out of it. I recomend buy it on sale. For $20 is not bad (as long as he continues to update) but not knowing the future i would pay like $10 maybe $15And let me just remind you I DO KNOW THIS IS EARLY ACCESS, i know thta has been a complaint thta people tohught it was all finished but it was cleared up that it is not and this review is for its early access, build 31 state.Pros:-Funny-Gorey-Mayhem-Nice 2d pixels and animations-4 player splitscreen-MODDING COMMUNITY!! (would only get maybe a couple hours out of it wihtout the mods)Cons:-Performance-Crashes, Bugs, etc.-Few  updates. Last one came about a month ago, but a year after the one before it...-In general unpolished (Ex: walking sucks, terrain doesnt always get dug up properly, little stuff like that)These cons can easily be fixed so if they do i will delete all of them and give a purely positive review on the game, because thats all there will be left to say.PLEASE FIX PERFORMANCE! My PC should not be having trouble with  a 2d game like this and neither should most other peoples! This is my biggest complaint!

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												The downside of this game is it feels rather limiting in some aspects. I don't really know what I mean by that... There's just a few things I'd like to do that I can't. Example, playing in a base between campaign battles. It would be nice to have a chance to dig out some debris and damage between battles, because you can only do that when under attack, and as a result of all the bodies I leave in my wake, doors end up getting broken. The base contruction could use more components as well. Some of the "odds and ends" have a left piece, but not a right piece, and vise versa. But that's just really knit-picky on my end.I love the concept, the plot, the art, the mechanics, the smoothness, the modding potential... There's so much that makes this game incredibly addictive. The Campaign is great. It has a board-game feel to it, like Risk. Triumphing against your enemies is really satisfying, especially when you come up with a clever stratagy (Tactical Skele-Brigade Strike FTW!).  The scenarios are great fun as well. I say this game is a great investment, and the devs should be proud of this work of art.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												One of the best strategy games I have ever played, if you would call this a strategy game. The unique idea and original story make this game interesting, but it isn't polished enough to be called a finished product.Start with a moderate amount of funds and take over a mining site on the planet. The amount you invest in an expidition is the amount you will have to purchase troops, upgrades, weapons. A small amount is taken right at the start of the battle in order to cover the cost of the brain and remote body. If you play smart and use the terrain and your troops effectively you will win without spending much. Simply pouring funds and troops into a battle is sure to make you lose in the long run.Overall the game runs fine. The graphics are almost dated, but they don't look bad. It almost seems like something from the late nineties. Most players will be challenged, but those who enjoy a unique kind of strategy will love it. Try to start a new campaign and learn some of the basics before you form an opinion. There are some bugs, but nothing game breaking. The devs are still working on this game and there's some great add-on content.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												This is a nice Indie game that could easily be overlooked. Everything about it screams retro side scroller, however I was pleasantly suprized to see alot of interesting gameplay mechanics. It's part castle defense, part RTS, part contra style shootem up. If any of these things sound appealing to you this may just be your game: building the most inpenitrable base, sending waves of units to take out an enemy base, or Running around blowing limbs of scores of baddies, Resourse management and development, or sitting back and letting the computer do it for you. The game is based in a very distant future where people's brains controll robotic legions to fight over resources. Everything about the game can be found in its opening cutscene (which might i add is freaken awsome) The core gameplay revolves around you Brain... both literally and virturally represented. The brain is either a moving robot or a static part of your defense that controlls all other actors and units. Its pretty simple kill the Brain, win the game. Initially when you occupy a planet at the same time as an opponet your brain will be air assaulted in with a few minor units ( In most cases a mobile sentry with anti arcraft rocket) From there you can call in additional units expending a gold resource that can be mined. Once a plannet is in your controll you can put your gold into building your dream base or have the computer do it for you. In the campain you set the number of factions and faction types along with the number of brains they have. Once all the brains are gone you win... or loose. Lets move on to the actors/units you can rain firery death with.There are a few tarting factions in the game ( which can be expanded with player made mods) Each faction has a pool of troops (actors) weapons, tools, and aircraft to choose from. In the campaing by selecting a certain faction gives you a discount towards thier troops and gear, however you are not constrained to just that faction type. When your brain calls up troops you'll have a window that you may select the troops and thier eqipment. You start of with how they get thier, what troop type, and eqipment thier carrying. The initial equipment and weapons is expansive, with every weapon and tool verying greatly between eachother. A unit can hold many weapons and tools and freely switch between them on the fly, however if you load up on to much you cant fly... This brings me to another point. All your units are equiped with jet packs. This is both awesome and fustrationg as menuvering your flyboys and girls cand take some practice; and will most likely end up with your trooper splattered against a wall or something. Its almost like Tribes meets Contra. The combat in this game can be pretty intertaining. All troops have body parts that can be blown off with well aimed shots; can make them beguin to bleed out or not. Another option is shooting the weapons out of enemies hands. The RTS aspect lets you select a groop of actors and set them on a patroll, Guard, Brain hunt mode, or designated points. You can also form a squad and have them move together and/or follow you. This is a pretty interesting aspect and gives the game some depth and versitility. If you feel like being rambo you can,  want to dropp in with an expensive hit team into the heart of the enemy defenses you can, or if You just want to send wave after wave of troops while you mine for gold Terraria style to fund it YOU CAN! This is a very enjoyable game and has many interesting elements not utilized by other games. It is however not without its faults. The AI can be less desirable at times, as in getting stuck or just flat out non responsive. The game has a tendency to crash when overloaded with actors in the campain feature. The campain is very easy even on hard difficulty and there are many ways of rigging your planet to be niegh impenitrable. It would be a great improvement if you could choose to drop a couple bombs on key locations before your very vulnerable brain drops from the heavens just to get shot down my spammed rocket infantry. All in all this is a great indi game and well worth a few bucks just to experience an outside the box game. It didnt have the backing of a AAA design team, yet still happens to pack some oomph.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Back in my young college days there was a downloaded version of this game going around amongst my friends (I really wanted to buy it but couldn't spare even the small amount of money required). At the time it was an unfinished sandbox where you basically downloaded mods and shoot crazy guns and stuff at terrible AI that practically just stood there.Now there's actually a game here. The campaign consists of taking and defending territories while competing with up to 3 othere AI players. You pick a place and if anyone challenges you for it you fight for it. Once you take it you can either design your own base within it, or pick a budget and let the game build one for you. I found designing things to be a little unfriendly because i wasn't sure what everything was, and it can take a lot of time depending on how crazy you want to get. Considering that at the moment the campaign doesn't usually last a long time depending on how good you are and the settings you choose I didn't feel compelled to do it. Additionally you'll be taking over several bases over the course of the game and it would be insane to manually build each one unless you were really quick. However, the autobuilding feature of the game tends to build some pretty decent looking bases. The problem is that each day you give the computer a budget for your base and then it decides how to spend the money and in what order. This means over time the base will get better but at the beginning you might have a pretty incomplete base. When you get attacked and you have an incomplete base, it can be nearly impossible to protect.The actual battles are where the game shines. You start with a brainbot or if you have a base he might just be a brain in a jar. He's basically your commander and if his fragile brain jar gets destroyed then its game over. I usually send him down to dig for gold while i let my other units guard him. This game is a physics based game where each pixel acually has its own properties. Units are actually made up of connected parts that move and interact based on their physics. This means that every part of a character can be blown off and every spec of dirt or other material has its own properties that can be deformed. Bullets go through softer objects and ricochet off harder ones. Rockets all have their own forces and when they explode they shred into pieces that can effect characters around the environment.This game is run by gold and every unit is bought and dropped into your scene through the buy menu that will let you customize the unit and what it's carrying. generally they all have jetpacks, and weight matters so you dont want to bog a guy down too much otherwise he'll get stuck a lot and won't be able to jetpack too high.Once a unit is called down you can take control of him and use his arsenal to take out other units and hopefully their brain. This is the part thats both amazingly fun, hilarious, and sometimes frustrating. The AI has gotten pretty smart at navigating around the levels and everyone is so fragile it can get pretty difficult, but in a good way. Especially when you're outnumbered and units are getting close to your brain. Having to fend off guys while simultaneously trying to buy and call down more units can be really tense. Especially because you're always working within a changing budget. Juggling shooting things, buying things, and budgetting can be pretty crazy at times.But the real craziness comes from the Cortex Command moments you'll experience. Blowing up dropships and having them rollover and land on top of the guys they just dropped off, then exploding is always awesome. Jetpacking out of control and then smashing into 3 enemy NPCs and watching everyone explode is hilarious. Sniping a guy from long range and watching his parts just fly off is super satifying, and if you get your hands on a rocket launcher, you're in for some serious entertainment. These moments almost never get old, and will keep you playing this game for hours on end. Even when you totally fail the simplest task and all these things happen to you, its still hilarious. And when you get bored? There are a bunch of great secenarios and community made mods on the steam workshop that will keep the game fresh. weegee's unmapped lands 2 mod is a really great conversion of the campaign and probably more fun than the vanilla game itself. He even has his own interpretation of FTL in the CC world that's worth checking out.I'll be honest, this game has a bit of a learning curve. In the current state I'm reviewing this game it's unfinished. The developer has admitted that all the features are in the game, they just arent polished, and thats true. There is a tutorial that does an okay job of teaching you the basics of combat and mining gold, but as far as the campaign part of the game goes, there's basically no guidance at all. The community has made up for this though. In it's current state it's a game you can sit down and play for 15mins or 5 hours. However, you can really see the potential of the game, and it can really only get better from here on out. It's a great game to add to your collection, play until your burnt out, forget about it for a year or two, and then play it until your burnt out again. It's that solid and that evergreen. You'll never get tired of blowing things up.Like the developer says in the video on the Store page. This game reviewed several years ago by alot of major sites in was was obviously an unfinished state. I'm not sure of the specific circumstances behind that, but this isnt the same game it was then. I'd argue it wasn't even a game then. Now it is, but still unfinished. The message here is, don't believe the major reviews or metacritic score. Read the reviews on steam. Everyone is recommending it, just like myself.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												I love this game. Never before have I played a game where you can design a bunker, set up turrets inside, and call down troops from dropship, each soldier chosen and customely outfitted by YOU. The entire game is physics based. The walking, flying, climbing, and crawling, is done with your own characters 2 hands and 2 feet. Also, the plethora of mods, secenarios, and minigames make this game fun as hell even if you exhausted the vanilla game. Most of the major problems this game had before (Stupid AIs couldn't follow through with orders, Glitches, and movement errors) have been fixed. The new squad system has made the AI competent at organizing troops. You can create a squad to attack the enemy base, and turn around and focus protecting your own.  Just bringing down soldiers is awesome. Nothing is as beautiful as several dropships floating down from the sky, with AA missiles rising up to meet them. The game is just so versatile. Need to clear an enemy bunker? Send in masses of cheap robots, clones, or zombies, or send in a heavily armed squad of tough elite units, or fricking have crash test dummies go the long way around dig through the walls to eliminate their defenseless commander.This game is special. It's mechanics are something I have never seen before, and don't think I'll see again for a along time.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												There are two things that really makes Cortex Command shine: The physics, which applies to anything that is active, and even to terrain to a certain degree, and the near-absolute modding freedom. Everything except the very core of the game can be modified, and you can also create your own content. Even the core is starting to get exposed with the new Lua compatibility! These mods can be anything from a simple pistol to a hypercharged giant walker with a cannon that can blast half the level away and so on. With your wobbly legged brain-robot you must destroy the enemies brain or on other modes... Faceplant into the ground, blow yourself up, snipe someone without legs, and ALOT more craziness. This game is one of my all-time favorites and will always be.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Note: I've played well over 300 hours in this game offline and off-steam in the 5 years I've been playing.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys fun games with a bit of strategy.Serving suggestion: This game is best served with a 3 gigabyte helping of mods. These can be found on the workshop.GAMEPLAYYou play on a 2D sideview map usually with your brain and the enemy's brain having to dig gold and purchase different 'actors' to be delivered from orbit for you to use to attempt to destroy the enemy brain.The physics in this game are very detailed and very important to winning. However, it may also be the thing that turns some people off. It makes movement feel somewhat 'heavy' and can be frustrating to get the hang of. But once you figure it out you'll be flying (yes everyone gets a jet pack) the body of your recently de-limbed trooper into the face of the enemy, hopefully decapitating them with the force... or maybe knocking the gun out of their hand... or the enemy might just laugh and shoot your face off.All in all this style is easy to understand and very fun to execute due to the large amount of actors and equipment you can choose from. However some things like the grappling gun and repeller gun are not very useful or practical in normal games.STORYNot much here. We're a bunch of space brains with unlimited armies at our backs that are ready and willing to blast each other for gold.GRAPHICSThe graphical style is wonderfuly done pixel art that isn't to pixely and is pixely enough it doesn't look cheap. It has just the right amount of detail to fantasticaly render every body part and machine piece as they explode and pile up on the map.CONCLUSIONThis is definently THE funnest game I have ever played in my life. The entertainment value is endless due to the active modding community and making mods yourself isn't that hard. It certainly won't disappoint if you can get used to the controls.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												This game is something special. It's a 2d realtime combat strategy. Everything is destructible to the pixel, and there's a physics engine at work as well. Shoot a human and they can lose limbs or bleed out. The environment is destructible, and the factions and setting is pretty interesting. Overall, a very unique and entertaining game. Those who like it tend to stick with it for years, it has somewhat of a cult following.I will say though, that if you're looking for a game that is amazing right out of the box, this might not be for you. Mods really allow this game to shine, and I would say that this game is only worth playing if you're willing to collect some mods for it. Void walkers adds an awesome campaign, and with a few others you can add thousands of new weapons, vehicles, and factions. I can't stress this point enough: mods turn this game from 'just ok' to 'using a lightsaber to deflect bullets back at the master chief while your psychic brain robot telekinetically rips peoples arms off'. 10/10, would play for a decade straight again

YouTube™ Video: Cortex Command Review 

			Views: 928		

			http://www.keengamer.com Cortex Command is a Sandbox RTS game crafted by the folks at Data Realms. Check our video review because Data Realms did not give up on their vision, and we applaud them for...		

I’ve poured in almost 70 hours into Cortex Command with no end in sight.  This may perplex you as Cortex Command was released in 2012 with… mostly negative reception.  However, the developers did not give up this project and have justified the 20 dollar price tag.  I’m usually not one to become obsessed with complicated games, but this game that has consumed me and make hours pass by like minutes.  	The story is a great backdrop for a sci-fi sandbox game, and set up the great motives for why you’re doing what you’re and that makes it good. When Earth ends, Cortex Command’s story begins.  Earth had become a viciously dark place, and the only choice the human race had was to leave.  From our evolution we cast aside our insignificant bodies as our brains alone, were capable to control multiple bodies in tandem.  This made it effortless to leave earth as we were literally just brains that could be transported easily.  When reaching the deep edges of space, we as a species learned that we were not alone as well as not important.  After some growing pains, we all adjusted to the alien life.  However, resources were depleting quickly and species started looking towards other systems which will hold the setpiece for a lawless, wild west type gold rush.  The artstyle of Cortex Command is similar to sidescrolling 2D indie games like Terraria, but it leans more on its physics engine to be pleasing on its technical side. The pixel art blossoms, and the physics are heavy and satisfying.  Robots have a similar weight to the B.U.D. in Grow Home, mechs look like controlling hulking metal, and mining in the completely destructable environments beholds an ambitious animation proposition that is executed perfectly.The music is a magically airy chiptune selection.  It sets the atmosphere perfectly, and is a great background to the hundreds of hours you will spend plowing through the wasteland.  Have you ever played StarCraft?  In a sense, Cortex Command is the same idea.  Two bases build themselves up as they slowly try to frame their offensive attack to take out the other player. Instead of controlling multiple units at once, you simultaneously control and give commands to singular units one after another with the flick of a button. You land on a planet and build your base to defend your brain, the juggling and resource management is satisfying and immensely rewarding as you choose whether to attack or defend.  You can allot credits to have more possibilities as you mine for gold and build up your weapons.  Planetary scuffles can either swelter to a grand strike after multiple hours or a swift contest mere seconds into the match.  Jetpacks allow verticality and become weildly after a few hours with it’s amusing physics build. Keep a FAQ in hand however, as the games tutorials can be complicated and enigmatic.Cortex Command is a Sandbox RTS game crafted by the folks at Data Realms, which is available for 19.99$ on Steam and Data Realms website. I purely suggest that you wait for a Steam sale and order multiple copies to gift to friends, as it’s very pleasant when playing with others.   Data Realm did not give up on their vision, and I applaud them for slowly improving Cortex Command into the game it is today.  Cortex Command is a game, that’s great for those who are looking for that new addicting game that stretches your dollar for hours upon each cent.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2013
												Cortex Command is an odd case. Having spent much of its time in development Hell and being released on Steam in what many believe to be an incomplete state, it's not hard to understand why the game gets a bad rap.However, underneath the bugs and quirks lies an indie title that does things quite a bit differently from others. It's not right to call it another 2D platformer or "a shooter trying to be Terraria". It's something of its own.Firstly, Cortex Command offers a simple and yet versatile file structure that allows an enormous range of mods. If the game bugs you one way or you want something in the game that isn't there, you're practically encouraged to do so. On its official forums, an enormous range of already-completed mods can be found, allowing those unskilled in development to pick and choose from the wealth of community additions.Second, the game offers something distinctly different from other games. It blends strategy and action together in an odd, yet enjoyable package, allowing the player to order new troops to fight their battles and manually take control of individual units to help swing the tide of battle. Indeed, it is entirely possible to win most scenarios by picking the right selection of equipment and going it alone - though it may be quite difficult, especially if one uses the frail brain robot for this task.Detailed terrain deformation and physics offer creative ways of manipulating the battlefield or assaulting enemy positions, where literally everything can be blasted, drilled, or bashed open with the right tools. Roughly everything is physically simulated, from sprays of dirt from a mining tool to an infantryman's legs in motion and even the debris from a destroyed aircraft.Which brings us to my third point. Cortex Command is, quite simply, comedy gold at times. Fighting off an enemy invasion with an armless and legless meatball of a man, using his sheer weight as his weapon, is entirely possible. Crashing a dropship full of crabs into a well-planned defensive wall and watching the gibs from the explosion kill everything in a half-mile radius is more than an infrequent occurrence - even if crabs aren't buyable in the campaign anymore. And with mods, things can get even funnier, particularly when they go catastrophically wrong.While a bit pricey for its simplicity, Cortex Command is still a game I'm happy to have purchased. There is one thing everyone should note before they take the plunge, however: Most agree that this is not a game for everyone and opinions are typically black and white; you either love it to death or hate it with a fiery passion. Try to get first-hand accounts about the game from both sides of the fence before making your final decision. And if you do buy the game, I do hope you enjoy it.

I approached the game wanting to take the time to strategize and build a base while the enemy built their own and apparently you can't do that against the AI, only other players.  Instead, I always found myself under immediate attack, often before I could get anything accomplished thanks to the horrible control scheme. content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												I've been around since 2008, saw it grow and all. Not exactly worth the money in its current state, honestly.Here are the pros and cons. The rest is up to you, dear reader.Pros:Physics, destruction of virtually anything pixel by pixelExtremely moddable (+now you don't even need the Datarealms' forums and the good old manual installation, lots of stuff is getting ported to the Workshop)Great spriteworkLots of fun in a metagame-based campaign, albeit an unfinished oneCons:UnfinishedWas an early-access ripoff before it was cool and everyone was doing itOnly local MP, no online play (splitscreen is still fun, but real MP is actually completely possible, as once proven by the awesome modders of Datarealms)Bugs, no mods/tweaks that fix themIn development hell still (+complete with Data switching to other crap)

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												It's a bit of a cross between Worms and Terraria. RTS with basebuilding, but the game has serious problems, not least of which is the developers seem to have abandoned it.- No default keybindings- No resolution options other than tiny window or (not borderless) fullscreen- UI is hard to find, much less understand- Units easily get hung up on single dirt pixels floating in midair; the physics makes units seem to shut down at times+ Great concept; with playtesting and polishing it could be amazing+ When the physics works the way it should, it's great; e.g. a cargo rocket exploding in midair and the debris crushing all my robotsOverall it might be worth it for some people, but not for me.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												The units you can control are very clunky and the most agile of the bunch are still difficult to move with. The game is NOT worth 20$. The game has many options to build your base, one can potentially create a large labryninth of corridors and rooms with intricate turrets and defendable positions. This isn't a positive though, as the annoying mobility of the game renders complex bases too clumsy to traverse through. The controls are bad and the game does not take it into account. THere are about seven scenarios to play on, as the multiplayer function does not function. The economics of the game do not balance well with the game. One ALWAYS has enough money to just create the essential unit to win. You don't feel any difference between units or weapons (of course there are the obvious assualt rifles and shotguns, etc.). The game is really repetitive. In a few reviews of the game on Steam and on Youtube, there were mods in the workshop to fix all the above problems, however the only mods are extra factions, maps, or items. You can download all the mods you'd like, however, the vanilla game's loading times are already terrible, and are made significantly worse with mods.

												Good concept plagued by horrible controls. For example, the "back" button wipes all your building or restarts the battle, losing all progress, without confirmation. Pressing "start" to try to start a mission instead sends you to the main menu, again with no confirmation. Controlling the drones themselves in an exercise in frustration, but that can be excused as intentional difficulty; performing destructive actions irreversibly and without confirmation at the push of a single button is inexcusable.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Cortex Command is fun. That's pretty much all there is to it. Mods are a must, though, as the vanilla game is... lacking(And weegee makes ♥♥♥♥ing epic maps). Although even with only vanilla, it's still a 2D side scrolling/sandbox shooter with pixel-based terrain destruction. Your bullets cut grass, make the dirt softer/break and makes concrete break with sustained fire. It's also an epic-moment generator, where your rifle's been shot and broken, all you have left is a pistol and a frag grenade, and you combat roll off a cliff, throwing the grenade, landing on another guy's gun, making him drop it, pick up the dropped gun, shoot down the first guy and then the grenade explodes killing the last one, making the victory screen appear.Yes, that situation was just another day in CC. I've jetpack-assisted flying-knee'd someone in the face, making his head explode before.

												Definitely an acquired taste.  It's OK if you don't mind the dated graphics.  The enemy AI plays well: but the actual game gives you few strategic choices. number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Great Game!It is completely different from what the trailer depicts ( I suggest watching a few "let's Play!" videos) but the gem that is underneath is beautiful...and a little flawed.The Game is a 2D RTS/Platformer/Action hybrid where you take the reigns of a disembodied brain whose goal is to become rich by claiming all of the gold mining sites on the planet's surface.Now...let me tell you the campaign is kind of dull (or at least I found it to be) but the varied skirmishes more than make up for it. The hilarity of combat is what makes this game shine, enemy drop ships landing on the planet's surface? take your trusty rocket launcher and blow it out of the sky, but beware! loose engine pods have a tendency to zoom off in random directions acting as a unstoppable battering ram. If you are successful in combat, holding the breach from waves of enemies, do not be surprised when the climb the mountain of corpses and attack from above, or mine below the surface, digging the ground from underneath you.What makes this game even better are the loads of mods found on the DATAREALMS.COM forums, adding factions and hilarious weapons to the gameplay.Catch it on sale and do not miss this. The company (and man) who made this game did an amazing job so show your support!

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												You need two things before you play this; mods, & a local friend to join you. If you've got both, this is the most fun you've had in a while. Any issues fall away the moment your skull is detonated from across town by Darth Vader packing a .50 Cal rifle, poised atop a pile of skulls, stopping you from suicide bombing his home base. By yourself-or, even worse, without mods- , it's startlingly average. The A.I.'s dumb, the controls can be damningly obtuse sometimes, & there are days you'll see the crash report more than the Main Menu. By all means get a friend and play this, but only at a discount, or hell, check all those Humble Bundles you bought eons ago, you might have a copy.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Cortex Command is an odd ball of a game. I bought it when it was first released to the public, in its unfinished stage. I played the hell out of it, dumped so many mods in there that it took it 10 minutes to start and I had plenty of fun with it. Its a great time consumer and there is plenty to do, especially when it comes to testing out weapons and causing massive destruction. However it is also a game with some problems - multiple maps have almost infinte enemies spawning (not the problem ;), but as there is not limit, the game will begin to lag. Of course killing them instantly fixes it - but it is a weakness.Another and more fundamental flaw from my view point is that I am never entirely sure why I am playing it. It is great to see a shot hit as intended or bomb the living hell out of a base. But when it comes down to it, I don't really feel productive. Yes, I did say productive, which is an strange choice of word, but I do feel productive when playing other games, it might not be the productivity in the form of work - but more in the sense that I am accomplishing something. This game is not that type of game. Its a game with a huge fun factor, lots of mods and play as you want. But if you a looking for more than a great way to waste time, then this game might not be for you (at least until an hour later when you want to smash some skeletons, stomp on crabs and blow up a spaceship so much that your computer chrashes).

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Cortex Command is fun. That's pretty much all there is to it. Mods are a must, though, as the vanilla game is... lacking(And weegee makes ♥♥♥♥ing epic maps). Although even with only vanilla, it's still a 2D side scrolling/sandbox shooter with pixel-based terrain destruction. Your bullets cut grass, make the dirt softer/break and makes concrete break with sustained fire. It's also an epic-moment generator, where your rifle's been shot and broken, all you have left is a pistol and a frag grenade, and you combat roll off a cliff, throwing the grenade, landing on another guy's gun, making him drop it, pick up the dropped gun, shoot down the first guy and then the grenade explodes killing the last one, making the victory screen appear.Yes, that situation was just another day in CC. I've jetpack-assisted flying-knee'd someone in the face, making his head explode before.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												I was at a stalemate against three two other factions: The Brotherhood of Nod and The Combine Overwatch. Somehow Nod had been able to kill off the Imperium of Man relatively early, although a contributing factor to their defeat was their strange compulsion to defend the tactically useless desert where their heavy units simply fell into the sand and were unable to retaliate.Playing as the United Aerospace Corporation I had the unique ability to deploy all troops and supplies to the field instantly through teleportation. This had worked in my favor until I found myself caught in between a firefight between Black Hand confessors and Combine Elites backed by several Hunters. The instant my forces were on the ground they were incinerated. My stubborness to admit defeat and simply wait for another opportunity to take the site got the best of me and my defenses were spread ridiculously thin. I had ended up taking the cliffsides but it was not even remotely worth the effort. I had an ample supply of brains to reclaim any territory that would be lost to the enemy, but no funds to supply them with backup and the ability to purchase new recruits. At the same time it was plain to see that with the Brotherhood of Nod sweeping across Combine territory and emerging victorious, they had no plans to halt their advance and give me time to save up the cash to produce an army powerful enough to turn the coming red tide. I had no choice but to perform an extremely stupid and desperate attack utilizing all the resources I had at that point against a single stronghold that Nod had dumped most of its cash in. If I could capture this territory I would kill off almost 50% of their units occupying the planet and also maybe gain the use of some Nod units as well.It was not going well at first, but then I massed a large group of minigunners and rifleman together on a high ground overlooking their main fortress. It was crawling with infantry and surrounded by turrets, but due to the sheer number of rounds I was throwing at them everything above the surface was slowly obliterated by an advancing swarm of lead death.Finally I was able to send in a modest amount of men armed with shotguns, chainguns and plasma rifles. I was slowly pushing their troops deeper and deeper into a retreat, forcing them to fall further back to the depths of their fortress, bottlenecking them. I had them. My initial strike force was getting weak, so I ordered them to continue onward without my direct interference. I produced another marine, this time armed with a BFG9000 and sent him in to finish the job. My men had managed to corner their brain at the very bottom of the base, but they were missing most of their legs and arms and couldn't land a shot. Their death would not be in vain. I fired the BFG directly at their brain and one second before it reached its target the game crashed.War is hell.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												  The game had potential, it really did. As it stands though the final product, if you can call this a final product, is not passable. The user interface is downright poor and for this game's concept to work it would need a fantastic interface. At the end of the day I might have been able to put up with the frequent crashes and lack of game modes and content in general if the interface were more intuitive but it simply isn't up to snuff. Without a way to quickly and easily call in reinforcements or to control those reinforcements the game just doesn't play well. It's a shame too because the games core concepts and mechanics are promising. Final verdict is that this game isn't worth the money even on sale.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												First Impression:Conceptually Excellent, I have been looking forward to buying this game for years.I just wanted to wait until I thought it was ready for purchase.With build 30 I decided it was finally time.I sat down at the keyboard with nervous excitement. I started up the game, watch a fun into video.Giddy with excitement I clicked the campaign, (not finished no biggie), and started the tutorial. Within seconds my excitement starts to falter, then fade.  I immediately realize that this game is only playable on a console or with a controller even though I selected mouse and keyboard controls. A few minutes later I find out that the controls are even worse then I imagined.  The same commands given over and over give different results. Pushing up and right to fire the jetpack will sometimes move you up and right, other times it will hover you in place, other times it will move you straight up.  The list goes on.  After playing for 10 minutes and accidently turning on the ai of the unit I was controlling so that it would just start doing whatever it wanted and override my commands I gave up.  With a heavy heart I still wasn't ready to give up.  So I pulled out my xbox 360 controller and set it up on my computer. After a few minutes I was good to go.  I started up the game switched the controls to joystick and tried again.  After loading up the tutorial I was met with being told to do things with [][]  with no buttons inside to let me know what to do.  So Knowing I was trying to select a bot I hit every button on the controller including pushing down the movement sticks, yet none of the buttons slected the bots.  So with all my dreams crushed and the inability to deal with the horrendous controls, I step back and write this review to warn others.I plan on coming back to the game next update and giving it another try, if things change I will update this review.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												I really want to like this game, but it's borderline unplayable on OSX. If some of the major issues get addressed, I'd be really excited to play, but at the moment I'm spending most of my time wanting to rip my hair out.  The idea of the game is REALLY cool, and yes, I had fun playing, but mostly it was an exercise in frustration.These are the major issues that I encountered:1. Broken 360 controller support. Buttons work, but not the sticks.2. Godawful frame rate at any resolution.3. Screen resolution options are terrible with anything other than native screen res. Smaller resolution in a window is very tiny, and going full-screen doesn't actually fill the screen, it just makes the same size "window" in a full-screen. That means lots of black with a still-tiny game in the middle.4. Fonts - anything smaller than native resolution (1680x1050 in my case) is unreadable.5. The aiming system is very difficult. Sometimes I get an aiming "reticle" so I can see where I'm aiming across the screen, but other times (even with the same gun) it's not there, which means you can't tell where you're aiming except to carefully watch the bullets.6. The jet-packs - after 2 hours of play-time, I still can't get my soldiers around using the jet-packs. Most of the time, they seem to barely budge my soldier off the ground. If a soldier gets stuck down a mine-shaft (or whatever), it takes so much time to get them back out that the rest of my squad is usually wiped out. Consequently, I end up leaving many squad members in useless positions and buying more.

I picked this up with birthday money that I got instead of Don't Starve, another game on the steam store, since it was on sale, and oh lordy I never regretted a thing. Maybe one thing. I don't know. I highly reccomend this game to people that want easily moddable (is moddable even a word?) and fun games. I write short reviews. Let me finish my soft taco. Nomnom.

number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												You want a review? ♥♥♥♥ you, how about a recap instead?I remember Cortex Command vaguely. It's one of the earliest examples of why early access shouldn't be a thing. The game was hyped up like crazy the first few years it was available. It was hard to be on the internet in the late 00's without hearing about it. People were hyped for a strategy game that implemented complex 2D physics. However, as time went on, the creator slacked in developing the game and lashed out at people who had complaints like "hey, it's been a few years now..." or "why am I paying $30 for $10 at best worth of content?". Overall, it lead to the Cortex Command we have today. It doesn't quite work as a sandbox, and it doesn't quite work as a game, either. It's fun to screw around with for a bit, but honestly I wouldn't buy it for more than $5.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												This is one of those games, and one of those reviews, that says "I REALLY wanted to like this."  On paper it has all sorts of coolness.  Base building, battling robots, a little platforming and a little mining.   RTS elements.  Lots of coolness. Alas... I can not reccomend this to anyone.  The robot controls are clumsy at best.  The campaign is some sort of unexplained turn based thing.  The AI players have no problem with their controls so they win a LOT of otherwise even battles.  But they also get confused by the terrain a lot.  And don't even get me started about how you need a magnifying glass to read any of the text that pops up.  There's a lot going on.  And a tutorial that tells you "use WASD keys to move, there's a radial menu, you can form squads, go get em'" essentially.  Getting to that point in a campaign is... confusing at best.  More tutorial info would hep a lot... if I could read any of it.Like I said, I REALLY want to like this.  But it feels like it aught to be an early access game.  My appologis to the devs but, I'm glad I didn't pay full price for this.  Thanks for listening.
