number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Very confusing UI and lack of customization for windowed modes. Also, it has a steep difficulty curve, and while challenge is nice, the game has no sense of pacing, so right away you're screwed over.A little clarity: it's basically a mix between tower defense and platforming combat. I don't know how to describe it, but the only word I can't use is -good-. See, there's very little room for error, and the game unfortunately makes you mess up tons of times. When controlling basic characters you'l often find yourself flapping around because of poor controls, and your guy will be sent flying to a part of the map you don't want. Other times the jetpack will just die on you, leaving your character to die.  As far as engagements go, you fight guys on the ground with ranged weaponry, but you and them are made of paper, so you die almost instantly when one sees the other. Even the tutorial is unforgiving like this, and you'll die if you don't shoot him the second he comes on screen. So above all, I would avoid this game, even on sale, unless you're intothe type of game I described. I wish I didn't have to be so harsh, but there is one last thing that really bugs me: no single player that I'm aware of. You get to play multiplayer versus bots, and online if I recall, but Im not too much into those, and for 15 bucks I was kinda hoping for it. Maybe I didn't look hard enough, but what can you do?

												Quite an entertaining engine and sandbox, with all manner of visceral pixel destruction physics. Quite admirable in that respect. I'm not sure how many sandboxy options are actually afforded to you anymore, that was from much earlier in development, and I'm sorry to say that the actual game portion of the game, in spite of continued revamps, just isn't even remotely engaging on an actually-playing-the-game level. It's remarkable fun to watch♥♥♥♥♥♥get destroyed, particularly dropships, but actually attempting to control stuff and do battle is an impossibly obtuse and clunky process. Even from its earliest days in development I was entertained with the engine, but really could not imagine how they intended to build a game around it.I'm still not sure that they did.

number of helpful: 9 of 26 people (35%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 25
												Cortex Command is a game where you have a Brain that is like a Commander, and you order units that are considored "Soldiers". You are also greeted by the Buy Menu. Not only that, it's a side-scrolling game where you have to defend your brain and sometimes kill the enemies brain but that's rarely the case. Now, to the part where the reason why I gave this a bad review. Cortex Command has been out for eight years. And it still hasn't changed drastically since then. All games should change in those years. Yet, the developers were extremely lazy and rarely update this game. The Developers also rely on the Modding community to fix and optimize their game. But what if they don't? I'd say, don't buy this game. The game is terrible. And guess what, this game is the only game out there that lets you buy units and deploy them from the skies, and control them manually too. I listed a pro's and con's list. PROSLag Optimization: Recently, the Developers released a update where it improves the FPS. Now this is actually good for a game, as FPS matters. Before the update, the lag was horrendous and I couldn't even stand it. Scenario Battle: Yes, the mode everyone knows and it is a truely loved feature by every Cortex Command player out there is the Scenario Battle. This mode is heavily modifable. As you can test out costume factions, units, weapons and more in this mode. This mode is infamous because you could easily add new modes in the Scenario Battle. Think of Void Wanderers for example, this mod was added into Scenario Battle to make it ten times more easier. CONSCampaign: The Campaign has a huge potential but the Developers didn't cared about it and didn't even touched it at all, which is why all Cortex Command players hate that mode. In this mode, you select your own faction and you need to rely on your own faction to build bases, defend and assault. What I don't like about the Campaign is that it has very limited scenarios to play it. And you would expect that the bases would be randomly or procedurally generated by the AI, well. Actually it's not. It is simple just a prefab of the enemy base.Boringness: Games are ment to be fun. And this is actually not fun at all. The reason why is because matches can take an extreme long time to finish, some matches do. The reason for that is the dumb AI, the AI controls your units and the enemies units terribly. Forcing you to micro-manage your units in order to make sure they are actually breaching in the enemies bunker correctly. The AI diffculty does not change nothing at all as well. AI: Yes, the AI is the worst. Out of all of the Cons, I hate this the most. The AI is just stupid. As I mentioned before, the AI has problems controlling your units and the enemies units. Not only that, they designate deliveries in the worst areas possible. For example, they literally order a Drop Ship on your built-bunker, drop units then get destroyed by your units then falls and the explosion bits hit your units and kill them instantly. Making the enemy unit safe. This is extremely unrealistic and unintelligant. Not only that, when breaching in your or the enemies bunker. They would dig to their brain instead, making the process slow when invading the enemies bunker. Instead of going in the best way, like entering a tunnel that is heading deep in the base, they would choose that. What's worst is that the enemy AI might notice and deliver units to the unit digging down. Inevitably killing them. In conclusion, I DEFINETLY do not recommend this game to ANYONE, only to those who like bad AI and very inactive developers. I certiantly hope the Developers will see this Review. I will change my review to positive if they update the game more often, but I highly doubt that. Don't buy this game until the developers decided to fix this game.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												There is a ton of elements in this game, that make a great game. You can tell love and effort came into this game. But, it is not a good game. It was not tied up properly, it did not run smoothly enough, some of the more basic elements of the game were just not optimized for fun. Some of this can be excused for various reasons, but it is still not enough to ignore the fun factor. It is slow. It is clunky. Much of the game is unweldy and not the most player friendly in design. I saw this game for a long time, had it on my wishlist and was interested by it. But then that new video appeared, really irked me. Something about it is really off by the attitude of it. Typically when a game retaliates to a review in that way, something was very off. The price irked me as well. As the years went by, I decided to finally give it a try.Do not buy this game unless you really admire its concepts enough that you are fine with trudging past the more painful aspects or you want to support the dev. Just, do not buy it thinking you will have a good time.

number of helpful: 2 of 19 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												It's rare that I'll say a game is terrible, but this game has the least intuitive UI in any title I've ever played, and that's enough to result in a terrible game. You have no warning when you're being attacked at the other side of the map, you have no way of knowing which weapon you have equipped unless you know the ammo quantities and which weapon "model" is which. The tutorial is a single level with a half a dozen sign posts to tell you how to play on a game with considerable depth as this, that is not enough. The floor seems to melt away as you're walking on it resulting in getting stuck in the floor. There is no progression to show you which weapons are better than other or which bodies are more capable than others. You get given a list of several hundred buyable items and get no indication on which ones are worth buying. The campaign is simply a series of skirmishes with a shared resource pool. The graphics are mediocre, looking almost as though the whole game and all the assets are developed to play in 640 X 480, aiming is terrible and unintuitive, sometimes working and sometimes not, can we have an Aim button so we know when we're aiming or otherwise. Why can I not see any range of distance when aiming, often having to approximate the thing I'm aiming at but I can somehow see anywhere on the map when I'm choosing my delivery locations?Personally I think the game would have had a lot of potential, but in it's current state it almost seems like the thing is having an identity crisis, it's like the game doesn't know if it want's to be a strategy game or a 2d action platformer. I think I would prefer it if it was played entirely like an RTS game and I could just pause the action issue commands to my troops where to move and which direction to cover etc. For a game which has been in development for such a long time, it seems that the developers have had no clear direction and rather than ending up with a solid game, have instead ended up with a digital identity crisis.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 18
 Absolutelly great game with endless fun Cortex Command is a really REALLY great game. It has the tactical feel of  "Should i send a squad of riflemen, or a All in One solution thats fragile?", but when enemy drop pods start crushing your people and when one of your allies "accidentaly" shoots a RPG at a friendly dropship you know you are playing this the right way.  But what makes it so great? Well then, sit down and let me tell you about the magic of a PHYSICS ENGINE in a 2D enviroment that is always fresh. You can literally use soldiers as a ballistic missile with C4 stuck on them, you can use a super heavy soldier with  Rocket Propelled Chainsaws  to annihilate a squad of enemies while a dismembered, bleeding enemy with a pistol shoots at your back. You can not decline the satisfaction of firing grenades into a bunker and remotely detonating it. Anything else? Well of course. You have the steam workshop with many GREAT mods like Void Wanderer which entirely change the entire point of the game, some mods with OP factions like DsTech with flashy weaponry and high cost. Or maybe if you just wanna mess around Hueg pack of mods with quality content like a nuclear fridge or a walking gas canister. Pros:  Provides endless fun The workshop provides quality content The physics engine keeps everything fresh and unpredictable For the amount of particle movement and physics the optimitisation is EXTRAORDINARY good Easy to mod, create content and overall costumisable Is even more fun in front of a TV with friends Cons:  The AI isn`t anything special but can be challenging The developers are a small, slow team but they still update The game is still a bit rough around the edges.All in all. This is one of the most under-rated games on steam that deserves more attention as it is unique and fun as hell.Really, if you can afford a couple of quid, pick this up right away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												I'm trying really hard to like this game, because it combines so many elements that I usually love: it's a sandbox (or rather box of toy soldiers) full of cool stuff with crazy physics, ragdoll soldiers, a totally destructible envirnoment... and yet somehow it seems to add up to less than the sum of its parts. Here are a list of some of my grievances:1) The controls, UI, menus etc are all very ropey and unintuitive. It takes a long time to get a basic grasp on stuff like the RMB command dial and the jetpacks for moving around, and the worst thing is almost nothing is explained to you, so you just have to persevere and figure it out. Now, I'm old enough that I grew up with games that were like this by deafault, but I think most modern gamers would find the lack of a proper tutorial inexcusable and annoying.2) The load time for the game is ridiculous; it's literally the longest-loading game I own by some distance. This game is a 90Mb download... how can it take longer to load than massive, graphics-intensive games? I feel like I haven't waited this long for a game to load since the days when I owned an Amiga 500!3) So many crashes, so much lag caused by too much stuff happening on screen. It crashes enough without mods, but with mods I can barely finish a scenario without an unexplained CTD or hang. Given the game's modding community is one of the things people praise about it, this seems prety unforgivable.4) Absolutely no story, nothing to work for, no progression. It even has a paltry 11 Steam achievements! I know it's a sandbox, but I feel like a structured campaign where you were slowly immersed in the game, unlocking weapons etc as you went, would make it a lot less overwhelming and keep you engaged for longer.5) Starts to feel very samey very quickly, despite the obvious diversity of units and weapons on offer.I'm only 7 hours in an debating whether I will put much more time into this, if I'm honest. I got it at 80% off and I guess I've had my £3 worth of entertainment from it already, but there's absolutely no way I could recommend this at full price. Pick it up on sale if you fancy messing around with it for a few hours, but don't expect a game that you'll love. It's a shame, as I really wanted to love it!

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
Why to buy:Plenty of detail, challenge and hotseat - multiplayer. If you are the kind of person that gathers friends home to enjoy game match. This is made for you in most ways. You can have fun for quite a long time. If you are the sandbox play with your self kind of player - you can really toy with it a lot.Why to pass: Single-player barely exists. All single-player options boil down to skirmishes that you can do for a while, but do not have a goal, do not build up and are not presented gradually. Think of it as a worms armageddon without the campaign and with everything unlocked at start. All you can do is hotseat with friends or play quick matches vs the AI.Value for money? I like to own games that have a certain effort put into them, and this certainly has plenty of that. The good news is - it has huge potential to grow. Maybe one day its maker would finally learn to work with its strenghts, instead of adding more guns etc.At the time of review I had 24 hours spent on it. 2 Hours spent being familliar with everything. 22 hours being my own entertainer until I moved on to something else. Not everybody is the sandbox self-entertaining type.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I have very mixed feelings about this game. I love the concept that combines real time strategy, shooting, and finance management. However, everything feels poorly executed.You move your units in the game using walking, which is painfully slow and a jetpack which has very little thrust and makes your character flop around like a piece of paper and get stuck on everything he touches, making it feel very awkward to move. Several times I've been powerless to defend my base because I couldn't move my units over a hill or wall to confront the enemy.The shooting is pretty well done, and I really like how your units' parts can be destroyed, leaving him disarmed, without legs, or blown apart across a large distance.The place where the game makes me feel most handicapped is when I am trying to order units. The menu UI works well enough, but selecting your units, their weapons, and the craft their delivered in takes too much time in the heat of battle, and there's no way to pause while doing it. Even when selecting preset units I feel much to slow, and usually you don't even get a chance to enforce your base with units before it gets attacked. So many times I've failed battles because I couldn't order units fast enough and was wiped off the planet by the AI without a fighting chance. Sometimes the unit delivery doesn't even work. For example, I ordered three preset units in a drop pod, the drop pod fell, broke through the ground and got stuck, and when it opened all my units' parts exploded out of it with their guns, the soldiers having been crushed to death.Overall the game feels very awkward and unfinished, but it can still be enjoyable. However, it is definitely not worth $20.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Cortex Command is a physics-based strategy-shooter. With much more physics than most other games you'll see out there, and the highest level of modability I've ever seen.It's difficult to say who will like this game or not. Honestly, it is. I know that I like it a lot. What I do know is that you might like this if you like: shooters, particle physics simulations, RTS, and blowing stuff up. The best way to figure out whether you should buy it is by watching gameplay videos so you know what it's all about beforehand.There is a catch, though: the game is single-threaded, meaning you need to have a decent processor to play this game at a reasonable speed, so don't get this if your only computer is an old laptop.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2012
												This is one of the coolest games I have played lately..  I really enjoyed this game a lot so far and pretty much love everything about it.  Definitely not the sort of gameplay for everyone, there is a blend of action and strategy.  The physics engine in this game is like nothing I have ever really seen before, and it is rather impressive.  Even more impressive is the devs next game engine already in the works.   You can make modifications for this game, and even your own totally custom levels with some additional programs.  The built in editor lets you easily remake the inlcuded maps.  I just wish it would not depend so heavily on the CPU because when action gets heavy this game can slow down quite a bit.  There are ways of getting around this though, tweaks to settings files and even the possibility to make modifications.  For me these tweaks seem to have fixed the issues mostly.Update:  This game still rocks IMO..  I'm really surprised it has such a low meta score, and that more people aren't digging it.  It has a ton of replayability, especially with all the awesome mods.  The ONLY thing I don't like about this game is that it runs poorly on my quad core because it isn't multithreaded, but the core engine was built a long time ago and would probably be a pain in the butt to redo.  So I can accept that, especially because it is still a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												One of the most creative and innovative games I have ever played. I bought this a few years ago and this still sits as one of my favorite games.There is a fairly large learning curb, as I can't even compare the gameplay to any other games. The closet I can compare it to is that this is like Wurms turned real-time with an overdose of action, a massive hit of strategy, and under all of that is a tab of freedom.There is a health bar, but most of the time it means nothing besides a bleedout timer as you can be instantly killed by a headshot or be crushed to death by your own dropship or rocket. You can shoot off legs and arms and sometimes it can even works towards your favor, but most of the time it doesnt as you hands to even hold a gun. Did your space rambo get both of his legs blown off and is rapidly bleeding to death? No worries, without those legs weighing you down you can jetpack much faster towards the enemies and then headbutt people to death as you fire your machinegun. But wait, as you move forward a stray piece of dropship debris hits you at 666km/h, killing you instantly. You are quickly overwhelmed by crash-test dummies with spacey nailguns and kills your disembodied brain because you spent all of that money on rambo and didnt bother investing in gold mining. All that is left is a fail message cycling through your screen.tl;dr Buy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I have very mixed feelings about this game. I love the concept that combines real time strategy, shooting, and finance management. However, everything feels poorly executed.You move your units in the game using walking, which is painfully slow and a jetpack which has very little thrust and makes your character flop around like a piece of paper and get stuck on everything he touches, making it feel very awkward to move. Several times I've been powerless to defend my base because I couldn't move my units over a hill or wall to confront the enemy.The shooting is pretty well done, and I really like how your units' parts can be destroyed, leaving him disarmed, without legs, or blown apart across a large distance.The place where the game makes me feel most handicapped is when I am trying to order units. The menu UI works well enough, but selecting your units, their weapons, and the craft their delivered in takes too much time in the heat of battle, and there's no way to pause while doing it. Even when selecting preset units I feel much to slow, and usually you don't even get a chance to enforce your base with units before it gets attacked. So many times I've failed battles because I couldn't order units fast enough and was wiped off the planet by the AI without a fighting chance. Sometimes the unit delivery doesn't even work. For example, I ordered three preset units in a drop pod, the drop pod fell, broke through the ground and got stuck, and when it opened all my units' parts exploded out of it with their guns, the soldiers having been crushed to death.Overall the game feels very awkward and unfinished, but it can still be enjoyable. However, it is definitely not worth $20.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 23, 2012
												I first played Cortex Command back in 2007, a demo for it was on a CD that came with MaximumPC magazine. The game was build 18 back at that time. I had a blast with it then for quite awhile, then forgot about it. Then in 2009 I rediscovered it, but found out that there was a ton of mods available for the game. I remember coming home from school day after day and just playing skirmish against the AI outfitted with modded weapons and characters on custom maps, I must have racked up at least 300 hours in the game, if not more. It was seriously the only game I played for a few months (hey, I had dial-up internet at the time and not a lot of money, I can't really complain)Some things you might find useful:This game loads all the files upfront, similar to Kerbal Space Program. The more mods you have, the longer it will take to load. Games like this REALLY benefit from being on a SSD or ramdisk. A ramdisk might not be necessary, but it depends on how much you play it, how often you reboot and how often it crashes on you.If you want a nice fullscreen borderless windowed setting for a 1920x1080 monitor, open up Cortex Command/Base.rte/Settings.ini and set ResolutionX to 960 and ResolutionY to 532, Fullscreen to 0, NxWindowed to 2 and NxFullscreen to 2. Then run the below .ahk file with AutoHotkey (or use the .exe version) and press Ctrl+Alt+G to remove the window's borders.If you don't have a 1920x1080 monitor, setting ResolutionX to half your horizontal resolution and ResolutionY to 8 subtracted from half your vertical resolution should work, but I don't have any other monitors to test it with. If stuff is too small on screen, you could try setting NxWindowed to 3 and set ResolutionX to 1/3 your horizontal resolution and ResolutionY to 6 subtracted from 1/3 your vertical resolution. If you have amazing eyes and want everything to appear at its original resolution (unzoomed) then set NxWindowed to 0, ResolutionX to your horizontal resolution, and ResolutionY to 16 subtracted from your full vertical resolution, but be aware that this is quite hard to see clearly, and is probably best for HDTVs or very large monitors.AutoHotkey script: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/25140621/fullscreen.ahkhttps://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/25140621/fullscreen.exeSpacebar or escape will skip the startup message and intro. Don't accidentally hit escape at the main menu or the game will close (which could mean sitting through another long loading sequence). Setting PlayIntro to 0 in Settings.ini will just throw you straight into the tutorial mission, so you could do that too I suppose.If you ever want more money in the middle of a mission, press tilde (`) to open the console and paste in:ActivityMan:GetActivity():SetTeamFunds(5000,0)Feel free to replace 5000 with however much money you want.And in case you were curious, my favorite mods from back in the day were/are AAL by numgun, DarkStorm by Darlos9D, UniTec by Gotcha! and Crobotech by capnbubs. UniTec has a massive assortment of items and characters, as well as some nice mechs. DarkStorm has a bunch incredibly innovative scripted items and characters which are a ton of fun. AAL has pretty nice heavy soldiers and a giant mecha with a big variety of weapons (however it's quite unbalanced), and Crobotech has some very fun polished weapons and characters (also relatively unbalanced).

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												so this gameit is a legitimate rival to tf2it has hats added in the last updateand zombies(jk the zombies are in mods)But in all seriousness, this game is amazingly good fun.  Who cares if it's still buggy?  Can't you people enjoy a game?  The basics are totally there, and with mods and a bit of tweaking to find which mods work with certain other mods, you get countless hours of fun.  The campaign mode breaks easily, but the scenarios are crazy.  I once went up against a bunch of guys with diggers (they dig and are an extremely powerful melee weapon) and I hid in a vent, shooting at the hordes of the "undead" while they frantically dug away at the vent attempting to reach me.  Luckily I survived long enough, and the mission was over, but I had to make sure to not destroy the bodies of the enemies as that was what saved me, the fact that the bodies were blocking the way.Honestly, I'd rate this game 9/10 IGN, it's like a 7.5 real review.  In my opinion, Metacritic is just plain stupid and gave this game a 44/100, because "the game isn't ready so therefore it can't be fun".  Screw Metacritic, it's an awful rating system.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
Why to buy:Plenty of detail, challenge and hotseat - multiplayer. If you are the kind of person that gathers friends home to enjoy game match. This is made for you in most ways. You can have fun for quite a long time. If you are the sandbox play with your self kind of player - you can really toy with it a lot.Why to pass: Single-player barely exists. All single-player options boil down to skirmishes that you can do for a while, but do not have a goal, do not build up and are not presented gradually. Think of it as a worms armageddon without the campaign and with everything unlocked at start. All you can do is hotseat with friends or play quick matches vs the AI.Value for money? I like to own games that have a certain effort put into them, and this certainly has plenty of that. The good news is - it has huge potential to grow. Maybe one day its maker would finally learn to work with its strenghts, instead of adding more guns etc.At the time of review I had 24 hours spent on it. 2 Hours spent being familliar with everything. 22 hours being my own entertainer until I moved on to something else. Not everybody is the sandbox self-entertaining type.

												Two-dimensional awesomeness! With its physics engine you can destroy literally every single pixel of solid material. Shoot your enemies with a huge selection of guns while standing in rain of blood and metal, at the edge of an ocean made of your enemies blood and bodyparts while rockets cash above your head and everything around you explodes! Not to forget the easy to install mods that are already available, and if you are into making game content yourself you can go right ahead and do it! This game cannot be played over the network, which is understandable (Have fun synchronizing thousands of flying pixels), but luckily you can play with up to four people on one computer.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												This is one of those few games I say is so awesome the trailer actually didn't show enough. So I just want to tell anyone who reads this abt the other features since it is a great game me and my brother play together. One is he fact that it has controller support, but you can see that on the store page. Second is the fully destructable environment and enemies. Everything can be destroyed down to the pixel, literally. You can shoot the leg of of somebody, or blast the gun out of their hands or even destroy the gun. The environment is also like this, you can dig trenches and wage a war like that, or instead you can use the rockets as missiles and bomb everyone. The more players the better, especially when everyone has a large in game budget, allowing them to fund huge armies. My only problem here is the fact that it may have a huge update and change some of the things that make it so unique and amazing, and I really hope the final updates are just focused on bug fixes, since it has all these features it basically created, and can definately say they ripped off me and not the other way around. It's a ame you can play with friends, family, and by yourself. The AI has a difficulty selection so you can always have a fair game or an unfair game to suit your masochistic needs. Worth every penny.

Posted: January 20, 2015
												been playing this one a long time (longer than my steam account) even made my own mod, so I have a faction. I play with my son, he uses a controller, i use the computer. Sometime i hook it up to the big tv and we play for more fun.    Your forces are robots, they can act by themselves, and are great at getting themselves killed. You will have epic moments when your commander takes aout a squad with his pistol, and you will have epiv fails when you accidently shot down your own rocket and it lands on your troops.   The game can be unpredictable sometimes, it goes with the game. The local split screen is the best.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												so this gameit is a legitimate rival to tf2it has hats added in the last updateand zombies(jk the zombies are in mods)But in all seriousness, this game is amazingly good fun.  Who cares if it's still buggy?  Can't you people enjoy a game?  The basics are totally there, and with mods and a bit of tweaking to find which mods work with certain other mods, you get countless hours of fun.  The campaign mode breaks easily, but the scenarios are crazy.  I once went up against a bunch of guys with diggers (they dig and are an extremely powerful melee weapon) and I hid in a vent, shooting at the hordes of the "undead" while they frantically dug away at the vent attempting to reach me.  Luckily I survived long enough, and the mission was over, but I had to make sure to not destroy the bodies of the enemies as that was what saved me, the fact that the bodies were blocking the way.Honestly, I'd rate this game 9/10 IGN, it's like a 7.5 real review.  In my opinion, Metacritic is just plain stupid and gave this game a 44/100, because "the game isn't ready so therefore it can't be fun".  Screw Metacritic, it's an awful rating system.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 29, 2012
												First impressions on this is that it is probably not worth the current price tag of $20. It is certainly a very interesting game, but it is lacking polish and feels like it is still rolling in beta. You play a brain in a jar with access to a satellite filled with munitions and robotic drones/minions you control to do your bidding. You are competing with other such brains for mining resources. Fun concept and the gameplay is certainly interesting, but I would never pay $20 for it. It feels like a $10 game tops in the current state. I tossed a few dollars to it back in early early alpha, so I lucked out in being able to try it with minimal investment. No internet multiplayer as far as I was able to find. It feels like a complex version of some of those old sega games you used to see. Maybe pick it up on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												I bought this game on September 30th, 2012, 2 days after it released on Steam, for $17.99.  Since then, I have watched the rating of it drop and watch as the game was dragged through the mud.  I have a tendancy to leave games for a while (especially early access), and try to finish all the games I have that are 'finished', so I can play through everything being complete.  Over the years as well, I have watched as it seemed this game was lost in the void of the oh so many games never coming to fruition for whatever reasons (owning some as well, of course).  It's pretty frustrating, however I played this game once, yup, One time, for almost an hour, that's my actual playtime.  Yet after all the complaining, and the Steam refund system coming into full effect (which I have used), after thinking this game was lost, and such a small amount of time played, the time I did play, through all the rough edges, I could tell that I would enjoy this game, someday, when I got around to it.  It was only when I left another game today, December 30th, 2016, and became really confused to see Cortex Command at the bottom of my update list, I was happy to see they are not gone.  So here we are, 4 years later, sure it may be some time before I really sit down and get into it, I will say, it does have a certain charm about it, that I could not abandon after all that time, ..is the point.  *To be updated*

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												My history with this game is...long. A long and joyful history where I spent hours looking at footage before buying it. Then it released on steam. Though it releasing on steam came with a lot of...stuff. A lot of my mods didn't work, so much stuff broke. Whatever though! We have WORKSHOP! Workshop is the BEST thing to happen to this game.Though I am not here to talk about that.Cortex Commands is a game I have played a lot of. On steam and off steam I have I would say 200~ hours combined. I ADORE this game to bits. It is under apreciated and I don't think its being updated anymore, due to the last update being in 2015...I'm pretty sure. My dreams of online multiplayer, crushed. If this game were to have that it would breathe SO much new life into it. I would also love that even more since being able to have long campaigns with online folks. A 1v1v1v1 campaign would be SO much fun with people. You may say "Oh, you have split-screen!" My answer to that is none of my IRL friends enjoy these type of games, also the split-screen sucks and the gamepad controls sucks. (IMO)The chaos that would unfold.I could also tell you about the game...cause thats sorta the purpose of a review, but I ain't. I'll just say go watch a let's play or something. That will give you a idea. I am just ranting about this game and how much joy it has given me, and I really hope that in the future it gives a lot more people the same joy I felt with my experience with this game.UPDATE: December 2016 - WOOO! UPDATE! WOOOOOOOOOOOOO!

												Overall a kind of "meh" game. It has a lot of potential to be fun, but the issue is how opaque a lot of the features are. The tutorial covers the absolute bare minimum of moving around and shooting, and the basic objectives, but does not cover anything regarding the career mode such as base building or even turn structure. Get it while it's on sale. At $3, I definitely feel I got my money's worth, but it's not quite got enough polish to shell out the full asking price.

												This game is by far one of the best sidescrolling experiences I have had in any game. From the sheer insanity of large scale battles to the tactical precision of small engagements, the game is incredibly fun. While it is not complete, it is updated (sporadically) and each update adds content and enhancements that just make the game more and more worth it to buy. I absolutely recommend buying the game, and can see it becoming a cult classic in a few years.

												Worms meets your favorite shooters. Worth every penny and great fun with a few friends and some controllers - I'd even go as far as to say this is the best local multiplayer game available for PC and I own Crawl, Nidhog, and others. If you've ever played with army men, legos, and action figures when you were young and imagined massive, brutal, battles this game brings it to life. Build and defend massive underground bases with traps and fortified rooms or storm someone else's creation while they defend. The community mod list is massive and always growing. I actually find myself removing some from time to time because the amount of choices can be overwhelming.

content:
Posted: April 20
												Cortex command is a strange case. It reminds me a lot of old PC games like Liero. I think the first thing to make clear is the game is not fun without mods.  The vanilla factions, whilst fun for a while are lacking in many ways and the stuff the community comes up with is much more interesting.The game has some great unique gameplay though. You control a brain, your brain and can use it to control bodies and craft that are called in from space. The game is a weird hybrid of RTS, Side scrolling shooter and Physics puzzler. Each body you control has physics and weight (giving them more weapons makes em heavier) lighter bodies can fly easier but will also die when colliding with concrete at high speed. Heavier bodies can't fly as well but the concrete will get smashed before their faces. The game also has a base building aspect (in some modes) where you put together a 'brain bunker' from various bits and pieces and defend it from people who do not like your brain. Throw in a few mods and the strange physics and unique gameplay make for a highly entertaining experiance....until it crashes.Cortex command is far from stable. It'll crash regularly once you get a few mods going and the loading time when booting up the game does make every crash a tragedy.All things said though I reccomend the game if you can get it on sale. Grab a few mods (I reccomend void wanderers and a few compatible factions to go with it) and have fun shouting at a crash test dummy to stop shooting the doors.
